2025-12-11 20:52:28,643 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug?

[A] : Increase in serum ACTH
[B] : Decrease in urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids
[C] : Decrease in serum 11-deoxycortisol
[D] : Increase in serum cortisol
<|end|><|assistant|> The metyrapone stimulation test is used to assess the integrity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. Metyrapone inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme necessary for the final step of cortisol synthesis in the adrenal cortex. This inhibition leads to a decrease in cortisol production.

When cortisol levels fall, the negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland is reduced, leading to an increase in the secretion of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the pituitary gland. The increase in ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce more of its precursors, including 11-deoxycortisol.

Therefore, after administration of metyrapone, one would expect to see an increase in serum ACTH due to the lack of negative feedback from low cortisol levels. Additionally, there would be an increase in the precursors of cortisol, such as 11-deoxycortisol, but this is not one of the options provided.

So, the answer is [A]. Increase in serum ACTH.<|end|>
2025-12-11 20:52:28,644 - INFO - question 174/1273 answer:A correct_answer:A True
2025-12-11 20:52:53,796 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An investigator conducts a study to determine whether earlier detection of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) in patients increases survival time. One subset of study participants consists of asymptomatic individuals who were diagnosed with GBM after undergoing a screening MRI of the brain. The other subset of study participants was diagnosed with GBM only after they developed symptoms. Results from the study show that the asymptomatic patients who were diagnosed with screening MRI had an average survival time that was 6 weeks longer than that of the patients who were diagnosed after symptom onset. Which of the following statistical biases is most likely to have occurred as a result of the endpoint selected for this study?

[A] : Observer-expectancy bias
[B] : Length-time bias
[C] : Surveillance bias
[D] : Lead-time bias
<|end|><|assistant|> The study in question is comparing the survival time of patients diagnosed with GBM at different stages: asymptomatic (detected through screening MRI) and symptomatic (diagnosed after symptom onset). The key finding is that asymptomatic patients had an average survival time that was 6 weeks longer than that of the symptomatic patients.

This difference in survival time could be due to several factors, but we need to consider the biases that could affect the study's outcome:

[A]. Observer-expectancy bias occurs when the researcher's expectations influence the participants of the study. This bias is less likely to be the issue here, as the study is not described as being influenced by the researchers' expectations.

[B]. Length-time bias refers to the phenomenon where slower-progressing diseases are more likely to be detected during screening because they are present in the population longer. This bias could potentially affect the study, but it does not directly explain the difference in survival times.

[C]. Surveillance bias occurs when increased surveillance (like screening) leads to an increased detection of cases, which could lead to a false perception of improved outcomes. However, this bias does not specifically address the difference in survival times between the two groups.

[D]. Lead-time bias occurs when screening detects a disease earlier than it would have been detected without screening. This can make it seem like survival has increased when, in fact, the earlier detection has simply extended the time from diagnosis to death without actually improving the underlying survival.

Given that the study shows an increased survival time for asymptomatic patients who were diagnosed earlier through screening, the most likely bias at play here is lead-time bias. The earlier detection of GBM in asymptomatic patients could make it appear as though these patients live longer after diagnosis, when in reality, they may not live any longer at all; they just have more time from diagnosis to death because the disease was caught earlier.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

[B] : Bronchoscopy
[C] : Emergency thoracotomy
[D] : Needle decompression

2025-12-11 20:53:16,390 - INFO - question 176/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True
2025-12-11 20:53:30,377 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A novel type of PET radiotracer is being developed to evaluate patients with Parkinson’s disease. A clinical research study has enrolled 1,200 patients, half of whom have the disease. The scan is found to be positive in 590 of the 600 patients with known PD, and positive in 20 of the 600 patients without PD. What is the test’s overall specificity?

[A] : 580 / (20 + 590)
[B] : 580 / (10 + 580)
[C] : 590 / (590 + 10)
[D] : 580 / (580 + 20)
<|end|><|assistant|> Specificity is a measure of a test's ability to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives) among all the individuals who do not have the disease. It is calculated as the number of true negatives divided by the total number of individuals without the disease (true negatives plus false positives).

In this case, we have 600 patients without Parkinson's disease (the total number without the disease). Out of these, 20 patients were incorrectly identified as having the disease by the PET scan (false positives). Therefore, the number of true negatives would be the total number of patients without PD minus the false positives:

True negatives = Total patients without PD - False positives
True negatives = 600 - 20
True negatives = 580

Now, we can calculate the specificity:

Specificity = True negatives / (True negatives + False positives)
Specificity = 580 / (580 + 20)
Specificity = 580 / 600

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>
2025-12-11 20:53:30,377 - INFO - question 177/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True

The bilateral wrist and knee pain, along with the presence of morning stiffness lasting about 50 minutes, suggest an inflammatory arthritis. However, the absence of joint swelling, color changes in the digits, dryness of mucous membranes, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and chills make an inflammatory arthritis like rheumatoid arthritis less likely.

The presence of non-tender nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints and tenderness at the base of both thumbs are characteristic of Heberden's nodes and Bouchard's nodes, respectively, which are commonly associated with osteoarthritis (OA). OA is a degenerative joint disease that is common in older adults and can be exacerbated by previous joint injury or overuse, which is consistent with the patient's history as a professional athlete.

Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents with axial pain and stiffness that improves with exercise, and it is more common in younger individuals, often with a family history of the disease. Gout usually presents with acute, severe pain and swelling, often in the big toe, and is less likely to cause the chronic, bilateral symptoms described. Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness, but it does not cause joint enlargement or crepitus.

Given the chronic nature of the patient's joint pain, the presence of Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes, and the absence of systemic symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis.

So, the answer is [C]. Osteoarthritis.<|end|>
2025-12-11 20:53:54,711 - INFO - question 178/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-11 20:54:31,815 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 40-year-old businessman who was previously well is brought into the emergency department by his assistant with a complaint of left-sided weakness after a chiropractic neck manipulation. He has never felt like this before. Past medical history is insignificant. His blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, pulse 86/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F). A T2-weighted MRI shows a left C5 hemicord lesion. The patient is treated with cervical immobilization, a course of steroids, and physical therapy. What other finding will most likely be seen in this patient?

[A] : Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion
[B] : Right-sided Horner's syndrome
[C] : Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement
[D] : Right-sided analgesia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a left C5 hemicord lesion, which means that the injury is on the left side of the spinal cord at the level of the C5 vertebra. The spinal cord is responsible for transmitting signals between the brain and the rest of the body. The corticospinal tract is a collection of nerve fibers that travel from the cerebral cortex of the brain down through the spinal cord and are responsible for voluntary motor control.

When there is a hemicord lesion, it typically affects the descending corticospinal tract on the same side as the lesion. This would lead to weakness or paralysis on the same side as the injury, which is known as an upper motor neuron lesion. The corticospinal tract decussates (crosses over) at the level of the medulla, which means that a lesion above this point would cause weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body.

Given that the lesion is at the C5 level, the patient would likely experience weakness or paralysis on the right side of the body (contralateral to the lesion) due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

Now let's go through the options:

[A]. Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion - This is a possible outcome of a corticospinal tract lesion, as it would cause increased muscle tone and reflexes on the side of the body opposite to the lesion.

[B]. Right-sided Horner's syndrome - Horner's syndrome is characterized by ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face. It is caused by disruption of the sympathetic nerves, which can occur with a hemicord lesion. However, the C5 level is not typically associated with the sympathetic outflow that would cause Horner's syndrome.

[C]. Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement - This is the expected finding in a hemicord lesion like the one described, as the corticospinal tract is affected on the same side as the lesion, leading to contralateral (opposite side) weakness.

[D]. Right-sided analgesia - Analgesia refers to a loss of sensation. A hemicord lesion would not typically cause analgesia; instead, it would cause sensory deficits on the same side as the lesion.

The most likely additional finding in this patient, given the left C5 hemicord lesion, would be contralateral corticospinal tract involvement, which would manifest as right-sided weakness or paralysis.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

Basophils 0%

[A] : Von Willebrand disease
[B] : Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia
[C] : Bernard-Soulier disease
[D] : Scurvy
<|end|><|assistant|> The infant presents with spontaneous nosebleeds, multiple bruising, and petechiae without any trauma. The vital signs are within normal limits for his age, but the physical examination findings of pale skin, petechiae, and ecchymosis are concerning for a bleeding disorder.

The complete blood count shows a low hemoglobin level, which is consistent with anemia. The platelet count is elevated, which is not typical for most bleeding disorders where platelet counts are often low or normal. The coagulation tests, including partial thromboplastin time (PTT), prothrombin time (PT), and international normalized ratio (INR), are within normal limits, suggesting that the coagulation pathway is intact.

[A]. Von Willebrand disease typically presents with mucocutaneous bleeding and may show abnormal platelet function tests, but the platelet count is usually not elevated, and the bleeding time is often prolonged.

[B]. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a rare genetic platelet disorder where the platelets lack the ability to aggregate properly due to a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex on the platelet surface. This would lead to an increased bleeding time despite a normal platelet count and function tests, which is consistent with the findings in this case.

[C]. Bernard-Soulier disease is another rare platelet disorder characterized by a deficiency of the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelium. This condition typically presents with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), which is not seen in this patient.

[D]. Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C and can lead to symptoms such as easy bruising and petechiae due to fragile blood vessels. However, it would not explain the elevated platelet count or the specific blood smear findings.

Given the elevated platelet count, normal coagulation tests, abnormal blood smear findings, and increased bleeding time, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.

[C] : Auto-antibodies directed against phospholipids
[D] : Resistance to clotting factor degradation

2025-12-11 20:58:33,519 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine. Which of the following will most likely occur?

[A] : The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
[B] : The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
[C] : The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
[D] : The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
<|end|><|assistant|> The ribosome is responsible for translating mRNA into a polypeptide chain by adding amino acids to the growing peptide chain in the order specified by the mRN[A]. The tRNA molecules are charged with the correct amino acids by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, which are specific for each amino acid. If a tRNA is incorrectly charged with an amino acid (mischarged), the cellular proofreading mechanisms should ideally recognize this mistake and correct it.

Option A suggests that the ribosome would recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine. However, the ribosome does not have the ability to remove amino acids once they have been incorporated into the growing peptide chain.

Option B suggests that the mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specify lysine. This is the most likely scenario because the ribosome will not be able to distinguish between the incorrect valine and the correct lysine once the tRNA is inserted into the A site of the ribosome. The ribosome will continue to elongate the peptide chain using the mischarged tRNA, incorporating valine instead of lysine.

Option C suggests that the mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome. While the cell does have mechanisms to degrade misfolded or damaged proteins, the mischarged tRNA itself is not a protein and is not typically targeted by the proteasome for degradation.

Option D suggests that the mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase. While lysyl-tRNA synthetase is responsible for charging tRNA with lysine, it does not have the ability to remove incorrectly charged tRNAs from the translation process.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

Erosion of tooth enamel (C) is a possible finding in patients with bulimia due to repeated exposure to stomach acid from vomiting, but it is not the most likely finding among the options provided. Elevated estrogen levels (D) could be seen in conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), but there is no indication of this in the patient's presentation.

Given the patient's symptoms and the context provided, the most likely additional finding would be an increased blood glucose level due to the stress of the eating disorder and the body's response to it.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

[D] : Quetiapine

Given the information provided and the typical treatment guidelines for panic disorder, the best medication for the long-term management of this patient's condition would be an SSRI, such as citalopram.

[D]. Effect modification occurs when the relationship between an exposure and an outcome changes depending on the level of a third variable. 2025-12-11 21:01:13,916 - INFO - question 193/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True
2025-12-11 21:01:33,337 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, Th1 cells secrete a factor capable of stimulating phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages. In addition, the secreted factors help activate macrophages to produce mediators such as NO, which are capable of destroying the invading pathogen. Furthermore, activation of the macrophages by the secreted factor eventually leads to the formation of a tubercle. Which of the following factors is secreted by Th1 cells and responsible for these actions?

[A] : IL-4
[B] : TNF-alpha
[C] : IFN-gamma
[D] : Histamine
<|end|><|assistant|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, the immune response involves various cell types and cytokines. Th1 cells are a subset of T helper cells that play a crucial role in the immune response against intracellular pathogens like M. tuberculosis.

Th1 cells secrete a specific cytokine that is known to activate macrophages. This cytokine is IFN-gamma (Interferon-gamma). IFN-gamma has multiple functions in the immune response, including the activation of macrophages. Once activated, macrophages can enhance their microbicidal activities, such as the production of nitric oxide (NO), which is a potent antimicrobial agent. The activation of macrophages by IFN-gamma also leads to the formation of granulomas, which are organized structures of immune cells that help contain the infection. These granulomas can eventually lead to the formation of tubercles, which are characteristic of tuberculosis.

IL-4 is typically associated with Th2 responses and is not the primary cytokine responsible for activating macrophages in the context of M. tuberculosis infection. TNF-alpha is also involved in the immune response and can contribute to granuloma formation, but it is not the primary cytokine secreted by Th1 cells for the activation of macrophages. Histamine is mainly involved in allergic responses and is not a cytokine secreted by Th1 cells to activate macrophages against M. tuberculosis.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

All participants were interviewed about their prenatal consumption of folic acid using standardized questionnaires. A 94% response rate was obtained from the surveys. The study ultimately found that folic acid supplementation was associated with lower rates of ASD in offspring (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Which of the following type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results?

[A] : Interviewer bias
[B] : Latency period
[C] : Recall bias
[D] : Survival bias
<|end|><|assistant|> The study in question is a retrospective survey, which means that the participants are being asked to recall past events or behaviors. In this case, the mothers are being asked to recall their prenatal consumption of folic acid. Recall bias is a type of bias that can occur in studies that rely on participants' memory of past events. It is a common issue in retrospective studies because participants may not remember past events accurately, or they may omit details they consider unimportant or embarrassing.

Interviewer bias (A) would be a concern if the interviewer's behavior or questioning style influenced the participants' responses. However, the question does not provide any information suggesting that the interviewers treated the groups differently or that their behavior could have influenced the mothers' responses.

Latency period (B) refers to the time between the exposure and the outcome. In this study, the latency period is the time from the prenatal folic acid supplementation to the diagnosis of ASD in the offspring. While it is an important consideration in studies of prenatal exposures and long-term outcomes, it is not a type of bias but rather a factor that could influence the study's findings.

Survival bias (D) occurs when the study population is not representative of the general population due to a certain characteristic that also affects the outcome of the study. In this case, there is no indication that the mothers with ASD children or healthy children were selected in a way that would introduce survival bias.

Given the information provided, recall bias is the most likely type of bias to have influenced the results of this study because it directly relates to the reliability of the participants' memory of their prenatal folic acid consumption.

So, the answer is [C]. Recall bias.<|end|>

[A] : Warfarin
[B] : Enoxaparin
[C] : Fondaparinux
[D] : Apixaban
<|end|><|assistant|> To determine which anticoagulant the subject is most likely consuming based on the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, we need to consider the pharmacokinetics of each listed anticoagulant:

[A]. Warfarin - Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and has a relatively slow onset of action. It is metabolized by the liver and has a half-life that can vary widely among individuals due to genetic factors affecting the enzymes responsible for its metabolism. However, its elimination is not typically characterized by such a consistent and rapid rate as 0.5 mg every 4 hours.

[B]. Enoxaparin - Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) with a much shorter half-life than warfarin, typically around 1.3 to 1.9 hours. It is primarily eliminated by the kidneys, and its clearance is relatively consistent. Given the rapid elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, enoxaparin is a plausible candidate.

[C]. Fondaparinux - Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that inhibits factor Xa. It has a half-life of approximately 8 to 11 hours and is also eliminated by the kidneys. While it is a reasonable option, the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours is slightly faster than what is typically observed with fondaparinux.

[D]. Apixaban - Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits factor Xa. It has a half-life of about 12 hours in healthy individuals, which is longer than the elimination rate observed in the subject.

Considering the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, enoxaparin (B) is the most likely anticoagulant the subject is consuming. Enoxaparin's elimination rate is consistent with the rapid and relatively predictable clearance from the body, which is characteristic of LMWHs.

So, the answer is [B]. Enoxaparin.<|end|>

[A] : Hypertension
[B] : Ovarian cancer
[C] : Cervical cancer
[D] : Breast cancer
<|end|><|assistant|> Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) have several effects on a woman's health beyond their primary function of preventing pregnancy. One of the well-documented benefits of long-term use of COCPs is a reduced risk of ovarian cancer. The protective effect is believed to be due to the suppression of ovulation and the consequent reduction in the number of times the ovarian epithelium is disrupted and must then repair itself, which can sometimes lead to malignant transformation.

COCPs have not been shown to decrease the risk of hypertension; in fact, they can sometimes increase the risk of hypertension, especially in smokers and women over 35 years of age. Regarding cervical cancer, while COCPs may slightly increase the risk when used alone for more than five years, this risk is not the same as the risk of developing ovarian cancer. As for breast cancer, the relationship is complex and somewhat controversial, with some studies suggesting a slight increase in risk, particularly with long-term use, but this is not as clear-cut as the protective effect against ovarian cancer.

So, the answer is [B]. Ovarian cancer.<|end|>

The fact that he recently traveled to Thailand, Ethiopia, and Brazil, where parasitic infections are more common, further supports this suspicion.

The indurated red patch on the leg could be a sign of cutaneous leishmaniasis, which is caused by the protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania and is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. This condition is endemic in parts of Thailand and Brazil.

The painless eyelid swelling could be due to a different parasitic infection, such as loiasis, which is caused by the filarial worm Loa loa and is transmitted by deer flies. This condition is endemic in parts of Ethiopia.

Given the combination of symptoms and the travel history, the patient could be suffering from a co-infection with both Leishmania and Loa loa.

The treatment options listed are:

[A]. Benznidazole - This is used to treat Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, which is not indicated by the patient's symptoms.
[B]. Ivermectin - This is used to treat onchocerciasis (river blindness) and strongyloidiasis, which are not indicated by the patient's symptoms.
[C]. Mebendazol - This is an antihelminthic used to treat infections like pinworm, whipworm, and roundworm, which are not indicated by the patient's symptoms.
[D]. Sodium stibogluconate - This is an antimonial compound used to treat leishmaniasis.

Given the symptoms and the likely diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis, the appropriate treatment would be sodium stibogluconate.

So, the answer is [D]. Sodium stibogluconate.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:06:24,588 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study and was discovered that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. Normal ascension of kidney during embryological development would be prevented by which of the following anatomical structures?

[A] : Superior mesenteric artery
[B] : Inferior mesenteric artery
[C] : Celiac artery
[D] : Splenic artery
<|end|><|assistant|> During embryological development, the kidneys ascend from the pelvis to their final position in the posterior abdominal wall. This process is influenced by the rotation and growth of the kidneys in relation to the surrounding structures.

The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is a key structure that affects the normal ascent of the kidneys. As the kidneys ascend, they pass anterior to the IMA. If the IMA is too large or if it grows excessively, it can impede the normal ascent of the kidneys, leading to a condition known as an inferiorly fused kidney or a "renal ectopia." This is when the lower poles of the kidneys are fused together, which can be seen on imaging studies.

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA), celiac artery, and splenic artery are not directly involved in the ascent of the kidneys. The SMA and celiac artery are related to the abdominal organs in the foregut, and the splenic artery supplies the spleen. None of these arteries would prevent the normal ascent of the kidneys during embryological development.

So, the answer is [B]. Inferior mesenteric artery.<|end|>

The splenectomy is successfully performed with removal of the damaged spleen (Figure C). Following the operation, the patient should receive which of the following vaccines: (I) H. influenzae (II) Tetanus (III) N. meningitidis (IV) S. pneumoniae (V) Hepatitis B

[A] : I, II
[B] : I, III, IV
[C] : I, V
[D] : III, IV
<|end|><|assistant|> After a splenectomy, patients are at increased risk for infections due to the spleen's role in filtering bacteria and mounting an immune response, particularly against encapsulated organisms. The vaccines recommended for asplenic or hyposplenic patients include those for Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and Neisseria meningitidis. These vaccines help to prevent infections that individuals with a spleen are more susceptible to.

- **H. influenzae (I)**: Vaccination is recommended because the spleen plays a crucial role in protecting against infections from encapsulated bacteria like Haemophilus influenzae type b.
- **Tetanus (II)**: While important for overall health, tetanus vaccination is not specifically related to the increased risk of infection due to asplenia.
- **N. meningitidis (III)**: This vaccine is recommended because individuals without a spleen are at higher risk for meningococcal infections.
- **S. pneumoniae (IV)**: This is another encapsulated bacterium, and vaccination is crucial for asplenic patients to prevent pneumococcal infections.
- **Hepatitis B (V)**: While important for overall health, hepatitis B vaccination is not specifically related to the increased risk of infection due to asplenia.

Given this information, the vaccines that should be administered to a patient following a splenectomy to mitigate the increased risk of infection from encapsulated bacteria are H. influenzae, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae.

So, the answer is [B]. I, III, IV.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:07:05,644 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Researchers are studying the inheritance pattern of mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene, the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis. It is believed that, in addition to the commonly found ΔF508 mutation, a novel mutation in this gene is found in a particular population under study. Which of the following would most likely suggest that these two loci have a high probability of being closely linked?

[A] : LOD Score < 1
[B] : LOD Score < 2
[C] : LOD Score > 3
[D] : LOD Score = 0
<|end|><|assistant|> The LOD (logarithm of the odds) score is a statistical estimate that is used to determine whether two loci are likely to be linked on a chromosome. It is based on the likelihood ratio test comparing the likelihood of the data under two hypotheses: one where the loci are linked and one where they are not.

A high LOD score indicates that it is very likely that the loci are linked. Specifically:

- A LOD score of 3 or higher is generally considered strong evidence for linkage, indicating that the loci are likely to be close to each other on the chromosome.
- A LOD score of 2 or higher suggests that linkage is possible, but not definitively proven.
- A LOD score of 1 or lower suggests that linkage is unlikely.
- A LOD score of 0 would indicate that there is no evidence for linkage.

Given the options, a LOD score greater than 3 would most likely suggest that the ΔF508 mutation and the novel mutation in the CFTR gene have a high probability of being closely linked.

So, the answer is [C]. LOD Score > 3.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:07:34,852 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 28-year-old woman returns to the clinic to follow up on a recent abnormal cervical biopsy that demonstrated cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) I. The patient is quite anxious about the implications of this diagnosis. Her physical examination is within normal limits. Her vital signs do not show any abnormalities at this time. Her past medical, family, and social histories are all non-contributory. Which of the following is the appropriate management of a newly diagnosed CIN I in a 24-year-old patient?

[A] : Close observation, pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months
[B] : Cryotherapy ablation
[C] : Loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP)
[D] : Hysterectomy
<|end|><|assistant|> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) I, also known as low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), is a mild form of precancerous lesion of the cervix. It is often associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The management of CIN I is based on the age of the patient, the severity of the lesion, and the patient's desire for fertility preservation.

For a young woman, such as the 28-year-old patient in the scenario, who has a normal physical examination and no significant medical, family, or social history, the preferred management is often conservative. This typically includes:

- Close observation with repeat cytology (Pap smear) in 6 and 12 months to monitor for any progression of the lesion.
- HPV DNA testing at 12 months to assess the presence of high-risk HPV types that are associated with the development of cervical cancer.

This approach is based on the fact that CIN I often regresses spontaneously, especially in younger women, and that the majority of CIN I lesions do not progress to cancer.

Cryotherapy ablation (option B) and loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP) (option C) are treatment options for higher grades of CIN (CIN II and CIN III) or when there is evidence of progression or persistence of the lesion. These procedures involve removing or destroying the abnormal tissue.

Hysterectomy (option D) is a definitive treatment that involves the surgical removal of the uterus. It is typically reserved for women who have completed childbearing and have persistent high-grade lesions or invasive cancer.

Given the patient's age and the diagnosis of CIN I, the most appropriate management would be close observation with follow-up Pap smears and HPV DNA testing.

So, the answer is [A]. Close observation, pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:07:47,501 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A clinical researcher is interested in creating a new drug for HIV patients. Darunavir has been particularly efficacious in recent patients; however, some have experienced an increased incidence of hyperglycemia. A new drug called DN501 is developed with the same mechanism of action as darunavir but fewer side effects. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of DN501?

[A] : Prevents viral transcription
[B] : Inhibits viral assembly
[C] : Inhibits viral entry
[D] : Prevents T-cell binding
<|end|><|assistant|> Darunavir is a protease inhibitor, which means it works by inhibiting the protease enzyme that HIV uses to cleave viral proteins for the assembly of new virions. If DN501 is developed with the same mechanism of action as darunavir but with fewer side effects, it would also be a protease inhibitor.

Protease inhibitors do not prevent viral transcription (A), inhibit viral assembly directly (B), or prevent T-cell binding (D). Instead, they inhibit the protease enzyme, which is necessary for the viral assembly process. By inhibiting this enzyme, the virus produces non-infectious viral particles.

So, the answer is [B]. Inhibits viral assembly.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:08:12,458 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An investigator is studying the effect of drug X on the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene on chromosome 13 in endometrial cells. Endometrial cells obtained from study participants are plated on growth media and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured with flow cytometry. Drug X, which is known to activate cyclin-dependent kinase 4, is administered to all the cells, and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured again 1 hour later. Which of the following is most likely to result from the action of drug X on the Rb gene?

[A] : G1 phase arrest
[B] : Prophase I arrest
[C] : Initiation of S phase
[D] : Completion of G2 phase
<|end|><|assistant|> The retinoblastoma (Rb) gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle. When the Rb protein is phosphorylated, it releases E2F transcription factors, which then initiate the transcription of genes required for DNA synthesis, thus promoting the cell's progression from the G1 phase to the S phase of the cell cycle.

Drug X activates cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4), which is a kinase that phosphorylates the Rb protein. When Rb is phosphorylated by CDK4, it becomes inactive and releases E2F transcription factors. This release of E2F allows the transcription of genes necessary for DNA replication, which is a hallmark of the S phase.

Therefore, the activation of CDK4 by drug X would lead to the phosphorylation and inactivation of Rb, which in turn would promote the initiation of the S phase in the endometrial cells.

So, the answer is [C]. Initiation of S phase.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:09:22,276 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> In order to assess the feasibility and evaluate the outcomes of cerclage wiring as a supportive approach to osteosynthesis in femur fractures, a group of orthopedic surgeons studied 14 patients with primary and periprosthetic fractures of the thigh bone. Union was achieved in all patients with a mean duration of 90 days, and there were no complications found in patients included in the study. The authors were satisfied with their findings and, due to the prospective nature of their research, submitted their study to a journal as a cohort study (which they noted in the study title as well). However, the journal editor returned the article, suggesting that it should be submitted as a case series instead. The editor made this suggestion to the authors for which of the following reasons?

[A] : No prevalence assessment
[B] : Low number of patients
[C] : Ascertainment bias
[D] : Lack of risk calculation
<|end|><|assistant|> The study described involves a small group of patients (14 patients), which is a relatively small sample size. In medical research, the number of patients in a study can significantly affect the reliability and generalizability of the results. A small number of patients can lead to a lack of statistical power, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions or to generalize the findings to a larger population.

A case series is a type of observational study that tracks patients with a known exposure, such as a specific treatment or intervention, without a comparison group. It is often used when the number of patients is too small to conduct a larger, more robust study like a cohort study or a randomized controlled trial.

In contrast, a cohort study involves following a group of people over time to see how different exposures affect outcomes. It typically includes a larger number of participants and often compares those with the exposure to those without it.

Given the small number of patients in this study, the journal editor likely suggested that the study be submitted as a case series because it would be more appropriate and potentially more publishable in this format. The small sample size is the most relevant factor in this decision, rather than the lack of prevalence assessment, ascertainment bias, or lack of risk calculation.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

What is the likely cause of this patient's condition?

[A] : Insulinoma
[B] : Factitious disorder
[C] : Hypothyroidism
[D] : Somatization disorder

[D] : Complete bed rest
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with vaginal bleeding, dull suprapubic pain, and a history of spotting, which are concerning for a possible miscarriage. The pelvic examination findings of a dilated cervical os and a uterus consistent in size with an 11-week gestation, along with the ultrasonography showing an embryo of 4 cm in crown-rump length and no fetal cardiac activity, support the diagnosis of a missed abortion (also known as a missed miscarriage).

In the case of a missed miscarriage, the most appropriate next step in management is to confirm the diagnosis and allow the body to expel the nonviable pregnancy tissue. This is typically done through a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure. D&C is a surgical procedure that involves dilating the cervix and scraping the uterine lining to remove the pregnancy tissue.

Misoprostol therapy (option A) is used for medical management of miscarriage, but it is generally reserved for patients who are not candidates for D&C or who prefer a non-surgical approach.

Methotrexate therapy (option B) is used in the management of ectopic pregnancy, not a missed miscarriage.

Complete bed rest (option D) is not an effective treatment for missed miscarriage and is not recommended as a management strategy.

So, the answer is [C]. Dilation and curettage.<|end|>
2025-12-11 21:11:41,441 - INFO - question 218/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-11 21:12:07,274 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which of the following layers of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?

[A] : Stratum corneum
[B] : Stratum granulosum
[C] : Stratum basale
[D] : Dermis
<|end|><|assistant|> Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate allergic reactions that occur when an individual who has been sensitized to a particular antigen (allergen) is re-exposed to that allergen. In this case, the allergen is peanut protein. The reaction is mediated by IgE antibodies that bind to mast cells and basophils. Upon re-exposure to the allergen, it cross-links the bound IgE on the surface of these cells, leading to degranulation and the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

The histamine released from mast cells and basophils increases the permeability of the blood vessels, leading to the classic symptoms of an allergic reaction, such as pruritic wheals (hives). These wheals are a result of fluid leakage from the capillaries into the dermis and the surrounding tissue.

Histologically, the changes in the skin during an allergic reaction like this would be most evident in the dermis, which is the layer of skin below the epidermis. The dermis is where mast cells are located, and where the histamine-induced vasodilation and increased vascular permeability occur, leading to the formation of wheals.

The stratum corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis and is composed of dead keratinocytes; it would not show the histologic changes associated with an allergic reaction. The stratum granulosum is a layer within the epidermis that is involved in the formation of the skin barrier but is not the site of histamine release. The stratum basale is the deepest layer of the epidermis, where new keratinocytes are generated, and while it may be affected indirectly by the allergic reaction, it is not the primary site of histologic changes.

So, the answer is [D]. Dermis.<|end|>

On physical exam, the temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). She appears lethargic and uncomfortable. Crackles are heard in the lower lung bases, with dullness to percussion. A small nasal polyp is also present on inspection. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the girl’s symptoms?

[A] : Dysfunction in a transmembrane regulator
[B] : Inefficient breakdown of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
[C] : Dysfunction in the motility of respiratory cilia
[D] : Deficiency in lymphocytic activity

[D]. Deficiency in lymphocytic activity - This could suggest an immunodeficiency, which could lead to recurrent infections. Which of the following findings will most likely be noted on spirometry?

[A] : Decreased FEV1 and normal FVC
[B] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
[C] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio
[D] : Increased FEV1 and FVC
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with breathlessness on exertion and a dry, hacking cough for several months. The presence of inspiratory crackles over the lung bases and the use of amiodarone, which is known to cause pulmonary toxicity, suggest a possible diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pulmonary fibrosis.

In pulmonary fibrosis, the lung tissue becomes thickened and scarred, leading to a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. However, the reduction in FVC is proportionally greater than the reduction in FEV1, leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio.

Given the clinical picture and the likely diagnosis of a restrictive lung disease such as pulmonary fibrosis, the spirometry would most likely show a decreased FEV1 and FVC with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio.

So, the answer is [C]. Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio.<|end|>

[C] : HIV RNA testing
[D] : Reassurance and follow-up
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn in question is at risk for HIV infection because the mother has HIV, although her viral load was relatively low (678 copies/mL) at the time of delivery. The standard of care for newborns born to HIV-positive mothers includes antiretroviral prophylaxis to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that all newborns of HIV-infected mothers receive zidovudine (AZT) prophylaxis to reduce the risk of HIV transmission. This prophylaxis should be started within 6 hours of birth and continued for 4 weeks.

HIV DNA testing (option B) and HIV RNA testing (option C) are used to diagnose HIV infection in infants and young children. Therefore, these tests are not used for immediate postnatal diagnosis in newborns of HIV-positive mothers.

Reassurance and follow-up (option D) would not be appropriate in this case because the newborn is at risk for HIV infection and requires prophylactic treatment to prevent transmission.

So, the answer is [A]. Administer zidovudine.<|end|>

The patient was diagnosed with diabetes 5 years ago and is compliant with her medications. The medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The physical examination reveals gross ascites and visibly engorged periumbilical veins. Bilateral pitting edema is noted around the ankles. The finger-prick blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL. What is the mechanism of action of the anti-diabetic medication this patient is most likely taking?

[A] : Binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor
[B] : Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell
[C] : Increased gene expression of GLUT-4
[D] : Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of worsening shortness of breath, increasing abdominal distention, and bilateral pitting edema suggest the presence of congestive heart failure (CHF), which is a common complication in patients with long-standing diabetes. The fact that her symptoms are exertional and improve with rest further supports this diagnosis.

Given that the patient is compliant with her medications and her finger-prick blood glucose level is normal, it is likely that she is taking a medication that not only controls her blood glucose levels but also has beneficial effects on her cardiovascular system.

Let's review the options:

[A]. Binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor - This is the mechanism of action of drugs like insulin itself, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for diabetes due to its cost and the need for injections.

[B]. Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell - This is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas, which stimulate insulin release from the pancreatic beta-cells. While they are used in the treatment of diabetes, they do not have a direct effect on heart failure symptoms.

[C]. Increased gene expression of GLUT-4 - This is the mechanism of action of thiazolidinediones (TZDs), which increase insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues. However, TZDs have been associated with fluid retention and can exacerbate heart failure, making them a less likely choice for a patient with CHF.

[D]. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist - GLP-1 receptor agonists work by increasing insulin secretion, decreasing glucagon secretion, and slowing gastric emptying. Importantly, they have been shown to have cardiovascular benefits and are used in patients with type 2 diabetes who have established cardiovascular disease or are at high risk. They can improve glycemic control without causing fluid retention, which would be beneficial in a patient with CHF.

Given the patient's symptoms and the need for a medication that does not exacerbate heart failure, the most likely medication she is taking is a GLP-1 receptor agonist.

So, the answer is [D]. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist.<|end|>

Option D, a hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumor of the myometrium, refers to a uterine fibroid. While fibroids can cause pelvic pain and heavy menstrual bleeding, the pain associated with fibroids is not usually limited to the days before menstruation and is not typically relieved by ibuprofen.

Given the timing of the pain and the relief provided by ibuprofen (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can reduce prostaglandin production), the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandins.

[B] : Albinism
[C] : Vitiligo
[D] : Melanoma

Melanocytes are the cells responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes.

[B]. Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a complete or partial absence of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is caused by a defect in the production of melanin by melanocytes.

[C]. Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks and destroys melanocytes, leading to well-defined white patches on the skin.

[D]. Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It typically presents as a darkly pigmented mole that can change in size, shape, or color.

Given that the biopsy shows an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis, the most likely diagnosis is vitiligo, as it is the condition that specifically involves the loss of melanocytes.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>
2025-12-11 21:17:41,961 - INFO - question 230/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True
2025-12-11 21:18:21,026 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An 11-year-old child complains of pain in the leg while playing. Blood pressure in the upper limb is 140/90 mm Hg and lower limbs are 110/70 mm Hg. There is a brachiofemoral delay in the pulse. Auscultation shows a loud S1, loud S2, and S4. There is a presence of an ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area. Chest X-ray reveals the notching of the ribs. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

[A] : Pulmonic stenosis
[B] : Coarctation of the aorta
[C] : Aortic stenosis
[D] : Transposition of great vessels
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical findings in this case point towards a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. Here's why:

1. Blood pressure discrepancy: The child has a higher blood pressure in the upper limb (140/90 mm Hg) compared to the lower limbs (110/70 mm Hg). This is a classic sign of coarctation of the aorta, where the narrowing typically occurs after the branches of the aorta that supply the upper body, leading to higher blood pressure in the arms.

2. Brachiofemoral delay in the pulse: This is another hallmark of coarctation of the aorta. The narrowing of the aorta can cause a delay in the pulse wave reaching the lower extremities, which can be detected as a delay in the pulse between the upper and lower limbs.

3. Heart sounds: The presence of a loud S1, loud S2, and S4 can be associated with coarctation of the aorta. The loud S1 and S2 are due to the increased flow across the aortic and pulmonic valves, while S4 may be a sign of left ventricular hypertrophy due to the increased workload on the heart from pumping blood through the narrowed aorta.

4. Ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area: This is typically heard in coarctation of the aorta because the turbulent flow caused by the narrowing can create a murmur that is best heard in the back or between the shoulder blades.

5. Rib notching on chest X-ray: This is a classic radiographic finding in coarctation of the aorta. The notching is caused by collateral circulation that develops around the narrowed segment of the aorta. The intercostal arteries enlarge to bypass the obstruction, and over time, this can lead to erosion of the inferior aspect of the ribs, creating a notched appearance.

The other options (pulmonic stenosis, aortic stenosis, and transposition of great vessels) do not typically present with the combination of symptoms and signs described in the case.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:18:47,868 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of excruciating left knee pain for 4 days. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen left knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. Analysis of the synovial fluid confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

[A] : Staphylococcus epidermidis
[B] : Escherichia coli
[C] : Staphylococcus aureus
[D] : Pseudomonas aeruginosa
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a history of total knee arthroplasty and presents with signs and symptoms of septic arthritis, which is an infection in the joint. In the context of a prosthetic joint, the most common causative organisms are staphylococci, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci, such as Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of acute hematogenous infections and is known for causing severe and rapidly progressing infections, including septic arthritis. It is a frequent cause of infection in the early postoperative period following joint replacement surgery.

Staphylococcus epidermidis, on the other hand, is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus that is part of the normal skin flora. It is a common cause of infections associated with indwelling devices and prosthetic joints, particularly in the subacute and chronic settings. It tends to cause less aggressive infections than Staphylococcus aureus but can be very difficult to eradicate once it has established an infection in a prosthetic joint.

Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are less common causes of prosthetic joint infections and are more often associated with infections in other clinical contexts.

Given the acute presentation and the fact that the patient had a recent total knee arthroplasty, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely causal organism, as it is known for causing acute and severe infections in the setting of prosthetic joints.

So, the answer is [C]. Staphylococcus aureus.<|end|>

Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?

[A] : Nucleotide excision repair
[B] : Non-homologous end joining
[C] : Homologous recombination
[D] : Mismatch repair
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the infant with severe sunburns and reddened skin in sun-exposed areas, along with irritated and erythematous corneas, suggests a condition known as xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). XP is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight. This condition is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, which is responsible for repairing DNA damage induced by UV light.

The NER pathway is crucial for correcting DNA damage such as thymine dimers, which are common results of UV exposure. In individuals with XP, mutations in the genes responsible for NER lead to an inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage effectively. This results in a high susceptibility to skin cancers and other abnormalities due to the accumulation of DNA damage.

The other options listed are different DNA repair mechanisms:

[B]. Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, which are not typically caused by UV light.
[C]. Homologous recombination (HR) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, using a homologous sequence as a template for repair, and is also not primarily involved in repairing UV-induced damage.
[D]. Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects base pairing mismatches that occur during DNA replication and is not involved in repairing UV-induced DNA damage.

Given the symptoms and the nature of the DNA damage caused by UV light, the impaired process in this patient is nucleotide excision repair.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

[B] : Dense fibroinflammatory infiltrate
[C] : Pleomorphic undifferentiated infiltrative cells with necrosis

2025-12-11 21:21:51,195 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

[A] : Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
[B] : The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
[C] : The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
[D] : The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
<|end|><|assistant|> Incidence rate refers to the number of new cases of a disease that develop in a population at risk during a specified time period. Prevalence rate, on the other hand, refers to the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time.

[A]. Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Incidence rates are not inherently higher in shorter time periods; they depend on the number of new cases occurring in that time period. If fewer people are at risk during a shorter time period, the incidence rate could be lower.

[B]. The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated. This statement is true. If you look at a shorter time window, you are more likely to include patients who were diagnosed at the beginning of the window and have not yet been lost to follow-up or died. This can lead to an overestimation of the prevalence because the data includes both new and existing cases.

[C]. The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods. Attack rates refer to the proportion of a population that develops a disease during a specified time period after exposure. Including attack rates in the calculation of incidence would not necessarily increase incidence estimates in longer time periods; it would provide a more accurate measure of the incidence rate by accounting for the number of people who were at risk and developed the disease.

[D]. The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Including attack rates would provide a more accurate estimate of the incidence rate by accounting for the number of people who were at risk and developed the disease. It does not inherently decrease the incidence estimate.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

[C] : Elevated serum TSH level
[D] : Mass in the sella turcica

These features, along with the patient's being a picky eater, suggest a possible diagnosis of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a condition that affects females and is characterized by the partial or complete absence of one of the X chromosomes (45,X karyotype). Common features include short stature, webbed neck, broad chest, low hairline, and lymphedema of the hands and feet.

Given the options provided:

[A]. Absent Barr bodies on buccal smear - This is a finding consistent with Turner syndrome. Normally, females have two X chromosomes and one Barr body (inactivated X chromosome) in each cell. However, in Turner syndrome, there is only one X chromosome, so there would be no Barr body.

[B]. Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level - This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are more commonly seen in conditions affecting the liver or bone.

[C]. Elevated serum TSH level - This would suggest hypothyroidism, which is not indicated by the information provided in the case.

[D]. Mass in the sella turcica - This would suggest a pituitary tumor, which is not indicated by the information provided in the case.

Given the patient's physical characteristics and the options provided, the most likely additional finding would be the absence of Barr bodies on a buccal smear, which is consistent with Turner syndrome.

So, the answer is [A]. Absent Barr bodies on buccal smear.<|end|>

Which of the following structures is most likely the origin of this surgical specimen?

[A] : Blood vessel
[B] : Pinna
[C] : Lens
[D] : Larynx
<|end|><|assistant|> The presence of type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate in the surgical specimen is indicative of cartilage. Type II collagen is a primary component of cartilage, providing it with tensile strength, while chondroitin sulfate is a component of the extracellular matrix in cartilage that provides compressive strength and elasticity.

Now, let's consider the options given:

[A]. Blood vessel - Blood vessels do not contain type II collagen or chondroitin sulfate. They are composed of endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and connective tissue, but not the cartilaginous type.

[B]. Pinna - The pinna, or the outer ear, is made of cartilage, specifically elastic cartilage, which contains type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate. This makes it a likely candidate for the origin of the specimen.

[C]. Lens - The lens of the eye is made up of crystalline proteins and does not contain type II collagen or chondroitin sulfate. It is not cartilaginous tissue.

[D]. Larynx - The larynx does contain cartilage, but it is primarily hyaline cartilage, which is different from the type of cartilage that would be found in the pinna. The larynx does contain type II collagen, but the presence of chondroitin sulfate is not as characteristic as it is in elastic cartilage.

Given that the pinna is composed of elastic cartilage, which contains both type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate, it is the most likely source of the surgical specimen.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

Therefore, the best next step in the management of this patient is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation and address the potential atelectasis or fluid in the lungs.

2025-12-11 21:26:54,042 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?

[A] : JAK2 tyrosine kinase
[B] : E2F transcription factors
[C] : Phosphoprotein p53
[D] : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors
<|end|><|assistant|> Carcinoma in situ (CIS) is a type of pre-cancerous lesion where abnormal cells are found only in the layer of tissue that lines the cervix's opening. These cells have the potential to become cancerous if left untreated. The pathogenesis of CIS involves the disruption of normal cell cycle regulation, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

[A]. JAK2 tyrosine kinase is associated with certain types of leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders, not with the pathogenesis of cervical carcinoma in situ.

[B]. E2F transcription factors are involved in the regulation of the cell cycle. They are released from the E2F-binding site on the retinoblastoma protein (pRb) when pRb is phosphorylated. This release allows E2F to activate genes necessary for DNA synthesis and cell cycle progression. In many cancers, including cervical carcinoma, the E2F pathway is dysregulated, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

[C]. Phosphoprotein p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a critical role in preventing cancer formation. When DNA is damaged, p53 can induce cell cycle arrest, allowing for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable. In many cancers, p53 is mutated, leading to a loss of its tumor suppressor function. However, p53 itself is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of carcinoma in situ; rather, it is a response to the abnormal cells.

[D]. Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors, such as p21, are involved in the regulation of the cell cycle by inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). These inhibitors can arrest the cell cycle in response to DNA damage or other stress signals. While they play a role in preventing cancer, they are not the primary drivers of the pathogenesis of carcinoma in situ.

Given the options, the most likely explanation for the pathogenesis of carcinoma in situ is the dysregulation of E2F transcription factors, which leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation and the development of the lesion.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>
2025-12-11 21:26:54,042 - INFO - question 249/1273 answer:B correct_answer:B True
2025-12-11 21:27:29,073 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?

[A] : PPV decreases, NPV decreases
[B] : PPV decreases, NPV increases
[C] : PPV increases, NPV decreases
[D] : PPV unchanged, NPV unchanged
<|end|><|assistant|> First, let's define the terms:

- Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease.
- Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don't have the disease.

Now, let's look at the data from the pilot study:

- The imaging test detected CMV retinitis in 25 out of 50 patients (since 50% of 50 is 25).
- The slit lamp examination confirmed CMV retinitis in 21 out of these 25 patients (20 confirmed by imaging and 1 not detected by imaging but confirmed by slit lamp).

Now, let's calculate the PPV and NPV:

- PPV = True Positives / (True Positives + False Positives)
- NPV = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives)

From the data:
- True Positives (TP) = 21 (confirmed by slit lamp)
- False Positives (FP) = 25 - 21 = 4 (detected by imaging but not confirmed by slit lamp)
- True Negatives (TN) = 5 (confirmed by slit lamp and not detected by imaging)
- False Negatives (FN) = 1 (detected by slit lamp but not by imaging)

PPV = TP / (TP + FP) = 21 / (21 + 4) = 21 / 25
NPV = TN / (TN + FN) = 5 / (5 + 1) = 5 / 6

Now, if the prevalence of CMV retinitis decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, the number of true cases in the population will decrease. This will affect the PPV and NPV as follows:

- PPV will decrease because there will be fewer true cases of the disease, so the proportion of true positives among the positive test results will decrease.
- NPV will increase because there will be more true negatives among the negative test results, so the proportion of true negatives among the negative test results will increase.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

[B] : Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
[C] : Twisting of the spermatic cord
[D] : Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis

[C] : Microcytic red blood cells
[D] : Bite cells
<|end|><|assistant|> Thalassemia is a blood disorder characterized by less hemoglobin and fewer red blood cells in your body than normal. Hemoglobin is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. The disorder results in excessive destruction of red blood cells, which can lead to anemia.

The beta-globin gene mutation that leads to thalassemia intermedia results in a reduced production of beta-globin chains, which are components of hemoglobin. This imbalance in globin chain production leads to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, which in turn causes anemia.

The type of anemia associated with thalassemia is typically microcytic, meaning that the red blood cells are smaller than normal. This is because the imbalance in globin chain production affects the overall production of hemoglobin, leading to less hemoglobin per cell and thus smaller cells.

Macrocytic anemia, which is characterized by larger than normal red blood cells, is typically associated with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not with thalassemia. Hyperchromic red blood cells, which have more hemoglobin than normal, are not characteristic of thalassemia. Bite cells are typically seen in conditions like G6PD deficiency after oxidative stress, not in thalassemia.

So, the answer is [C]. Microcytic red blood cells.<|end|>
2025-12-11 21:30:24,313 - INFO - question 256/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-11 21:30:53,793 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 68-year-old man from California presents for a routine checkup. He does not have any complaints. He says that he has tried to keep himself healthy and active by jogging and gardening since his retirement at age 50. He adds that he spends his mornings in the park and his afternoons in his garden. [A]. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that typically presents with well-demarcated, scaly plaques. It is not typically associated with sun exposure.

[B]. Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin growth that often appears in middle-aged and older adults. It has a waxy, stuck-on appearance and is not related to sun exposure.

[D]. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a type of skin cancer that can develop from actinic keratosis. It often presents as a firm, red nodule, or a flat lesion with a scaly, crusted surface.

Given the patient's history of significant sun exposure and the description of the lesion, actinic keratosis is the most likely diagnosis. Actinic keratosis is a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma, but the question asks for the most likely diagnosis, not the potential progression.

So, the answer is [C]. Actinic keratosis.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:31:22,991 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A routine newborn screening test for phenylketonuria in a male neonate shows a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20). Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?

[A] : Tyrosine
[B] : Pyridoxine
[C] : Thiamine
[D] : Tetrahydrobiopterin
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn screening test result showing a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL, which is above the normal range, indicates phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. Without this enzyme, phenylalanine accumulates in the body, leading to various health problems, including intellectual disability, if not treated.

The patient was started on a special diet to manage hyperphenylalaninemia, which is the high level of phenylalanine in the blood. This diet typically restricts phenylalanine intake to prevent further accumulation. However, the patient still presents with symptoms such as head lag, blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, generalized hypotonia, and elevated serum prolactin levels. These symptoms suggest that the patient may have developed complications from PKU, such as intellectual disability and possibly other issues related to low levels of tyrosine, which is normally produced from phenylalanine.

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is a cofactor for phenylalanine hydroxylase and other enzymes in the tyrosine degradation pathway. A deficiency in BH4 can lead to a form of PKU that is responsive to BH4 supplementation. Since the patient's symptoms suggest a complication from PKU that may be related to a BH4 deficiency, supplementation with tetrahydrobiopterin could help to prevent further complications by enhancing the residual activity of phenylalanine hydroxylase and other BH4-dependent enzymes, thereby reducing phenylalanine levels and increasing tyrosine levels.

So, the answer is [D]. Tetrahydrobiopterin.<|end|>

[C] : Increased GABA production

This would result in decreased homocysteine degradation and could contribute to the development of megaloblastic anemia.

2025-12-11 21:33:46,561 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. He is lethargic and disoriented. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
 $$$ Serum osmolality %%% Urine sodium %%% Serum aldosterone $$$

[A] : ↓ ↓ ↓
[B] : ↑ ↓ normal
[C] : ↓ ↑ ↑
[D] : ↓ ↑ ↓
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with confusion, a history of ischemic stroke, and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The laboratory findings show hyponatremia (serum sodium of 119 mEq/L) and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) concentration. These findings suggest that the patient is likely suffering from the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

In SIADH, there is an excessive release of ADH, which leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and concentrated urine. The body's response to the dilutional hyponatremia is to conserve sodium, which is mediated by aldosterone. Therefore, in SIADH, we would expect:

- Serum osmolality to be low (↓) because of the dilutional effect of retained water.
- Urine sodium to be low (↓) because the kidneys are trying to conserve sodium in response to the perceived low serum sodium level.
- Serum aldosterone to be low (↓) because the primary problem is the inappropriate secretion of ADH, not aldosterone. Aldosterone would be low because the body is attempting to conserve sodium, and there is no need for the additional aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption.

So, the answer is [A]. ↓ ↓ ↓<|end|>

[B] : Short-acting benzodiazepines
[C] : Systematic desensitization
[D] : Cognitive behavioral therapy
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing a specific phobia, which is an intense, irrational fear of a specific object or situation that is out of proportion to the actual danger posed. In this case, the woman has an irrational fear of dogs.

[A]. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs typically used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. They can be helpful in the treatment of specific phobias, but they are not considered the definitive treatment.

[B]. Short-acting benzodiazepines can be used for the acute management of anxiety symptoms, but they are not a definitive treatment for specific phobias and are not recommended for long-term use due to the risk of dependence and withdrawal issues.

[C]. Systematic desensitization is a type of behavioral therapy that is considered the gold standard for treating specific phobias. It involves gradually exposing the patient to the feared object or situation in a controlled and systematic way, starting with the least anxiety-provoking situations and slowly working up to more challenging exposures. While CBT is effective, systematic desensitization is a specific type of CBT that is particularly well-suited for treating phobias.

2025-12-11 21:36:10,354 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 34-year-old male suffers from inherited hemophilia A. He and his wife have three unaffected daughters. What is the probability that the second daughter is a carrier of the disease?

[A] : 0%
[B] : 25%
[C] : 50%
[D] : 100%
<|end|><|assistant|> Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, which means that the gene causing hemophilia is located on the X chromosome. Males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY), while females have two X chromosomes (XX).

Since the male in the question has hemophilia A, he has the hemophilia gene on his X chromosome. His Y chromosome does not carry the gene for hemophilia. When he has children, he will pass on either his X chromosome with the hemophilia gene or his Y chromosome to his daughters (who will all be XX) and his Y chromosome to his sons (who will all be XY).

The daughters of a man with hemophilia A will all inherit their father's X chromosome with the hemophilia gene, because that is the only X chromosome they can receive from him. Therefore, all of his daughters will be carriers of the disease, as they will have one normal X chromosome (from their mother) and one X chromosome with the hemophilia gene (from their father).

So, the probability that the second daughter is a carrier of the disease is 100%.

So, the answer is [D]. 100%.<|end|>
