During these episodes, she experiences a depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires less sleep than usual. Her past medical history is notable for obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

[A] : Bipolar I disorder
[B] : Cyclothymic disorder
[C] : Persistent depressive disorder
[D] : Schizoaffective disorder
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms include periods of depressed mood that last 4-6 weeks, with episodes of elevated mood that are characterized by increased productivity and decreased need for sleep. These episodes of elevated mood are indicative of hypomania or mania, which are key features in bipolar disorders.

Bipolar I disorder is characterized by manic episodes that last at least 7 days, or by manic symptoms that are so severe that the person needs immediate hospital care. Depressive episodes typically occur as well, usually lasting at least 2 weeks. The patient's history of elevated mood episodes that are not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning (as there is no mention of such impairment) suggests hypomania rather than full-blown mania.

Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms lasting for at least 2 years (1 year in children and adolescents). However, the symptoms do not meet the diagnostic requirements for a hypomanic episode and a depressive episode.

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) involves a depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, for at least 2 years. The patient does have depressive episodes, but the presence of elevated mood episodes makes this diagnosis less likely.

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by a mood disorder component (either depression or mania) along with symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations or delusions. There is no mention of psychotic symptoms in the patient's history.

Given the presence of both depressive and hypomanic episodes, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is Bipolar II disorder, which is characterized by a pattern of depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes, but not the full-blown manic episodes that are characteristic of Bipolar I disorder.

2025-12-12 04:02:59,012 - INFO - question 1107/1273 answer:A correct_answer:B False
2025-12-12 04:03:25,720 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks one mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. When compared to a healthy 20-year-old woman, which of the following changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?

[A] : Increased lung compliance
[B] : Decreased residual volume
[C] : Increased chest wall compliance
[D] : Decreased A-a gradient
<|end|><|assistant|> As people age, several changes occur in the respiratory system that can affect lung function. These changes include:

[A]. Increased lung compliance: Lung compliance refers to the ability of the lung to stretch and expand. In general, lung compliance increases with age due to the loss of elastic recoil of the lung tissue. This means that the lungs are more easily inflated at the expense of less effective expiration.

[B]. Decreased residual volume: Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. In older adults, due to decreased chest wall compliance and increased lung compliance, the residual volume may actually increase, not decrease.

[C]. Increased chest wall compliance: Chest wall compliance refers to the ease with which the chest wall expands. As people age, the chest wall becomes stiffer due to changes in the costal cartilages and the rib cage, which leads to decreased, not increased, chest wall compliance.

[D]. Decreased A-a gradient: The alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient is the difference between the alveolar concentration (A) of oxygen and the arterial (a) concentration of oxygen. With aging, the A-a gradient typically increases due to factors such as decreased lung function and increased ventilation-perfusion mismatch, not decreases.

Given these considerations, the most likely change in respiratory function in a 76-year-old woman compared to a healthy 20-year-old woman is increased lung compliance.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>
2025-12-12 04:03:25,720 - INFO - question 1108/1273 answer:A correct_answer:A True
2025-12-12 04:03:58,791 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 32-year-old man jumps off a 3 story building during a suicide attempt. Paramedics arrive quickly, and he is taken to the hospital where several stable lumbar fractures and a shattered right calcaneus are found. He undergoes surgery and his calcaneus is repaired with 11 screws. Which of the following statements best describes the long term post-surgery outcome in this patient?

[A] : He will not be able to plantar flex his foot.
[B] : He will not be able to point his toe.
[C] : He will have pain with inversion and eversion of his foot.
[D] : He will have pain while dorsiflexing his foot.
<|end|><|assistant|> The calcaneus, or heel bone, is an important structure for foot mechanics, particularly in relation to plantar flexion and inversion/eversion movements. Plantar flexion is the movement of pointing the toes downward, as if standing on tiptoes, and is primarily controlled by the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, which insert onto the calcaneus via the Achilles tendon. Inversion and eversion are movements that tilt the sole of the foot inward or outward, respectively, and are controlled by various muscles in the foot and ankle.

If the patient's calcaneus is repaired with screws, the surgery aims to stabilize the bone and allow for proper healing. Assuming the surgery is successful and there are no complications, the patient should be able to regain function in the foot.

[A]. He will not be able to plantar flex his foot. - This is unlikely if the surgery is successful, as the muscles responsible for plantar flexion should still be able to attach to the repaired calcaneus.

[B]. He will not be able to point his toe. - Pointing the toe is essentially another way of saying he can plantar flex the foot, so this is also unlikely if the surgery is successful.

[C]. He will have pain with inversion and eversion of his foot. - This could be a possibility if there is residual pain from the surgery or if there are other complications affecting the tendons or ligaments involved in inversion and eversion.

[D]. He will have pain while dorsiflexing his foot. - Dorsiflexion is the movement of lifting the foot upwards towards the shin, which is controlled by the tibialis anterior muscle and other dorsiflexors. This movement is not directly related to the calcaneus, so pain during dorsiflexion would not be expected from a repair of the calcaneus.

Given these considerations, the most likely long-term post-surgery outcome, assuming a successful repair, would be that the patient would not have issues with plantar flexion, pointing the toe, or dorsiflexion. However, there could be pain associated with inversion and eversion if there are complications or residual issues with the tendons or ligaments involved in these movements.

So, the answer is [C]. He will have pain with inversion and eversion of his foot.<|end|>

[B]. Amphotericin B and flucytosine

This combination is used to treat the infection aggressively, and after the patient stabilizes, fluconazole is typically used for maintenance therapy.

So, the answer is [B]. Amphotericin B and flucytosine.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:04:48,080 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A previously healthy 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain at the back of his left ankle. His mother had a myocardial infarction at 54 years. His BMI is 23 kg/m2. There is tenderness above the left posterior calcaneus and a firm, 3-cm, skin-colored nodule that moves with the left Achilles tendon. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of the nodule is shown. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show increased levels of which of the following?

[A] : Rheumatoid factor
[B] : Angiotensin converting enzyme
[C] : Low-density lipoprotein
[D] : Triglycerides
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of a painful nodule at the back of the ankle that moves with the Achilles tendon in a young patient is highly suggestive of a Baker's cyst, also known as a popliteal cyst. This is a fluid-filled cyst that extends from the knee joint into the popliteal fossa, which is located at the back of the knee. The firm, skin-colored nodule that moves with the Achilles tendon is likely the bulbous end of the cyst, which is attached to the tendon.

Baker's cysts are often associated with underlying knee joint pathology, such as meniscal tears, chondromalacia, or synovitis. They can also be associated with systemic conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, but in a young, previously healthy individual without other systemic symptoms, this is less likely.

The serum studies in a patient with a Baker's cyst are most likely to show increased levels of inflammatory markers, such as C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), rather than the options provided. However, among the given choices, the one that could be associated with inflammation is rheumatoid factor (A), which is an antibody that can be elevated in rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune conditions.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (B) is associated with sarcoidosis, which is not indicated by the clinical scenario. Low-density lipoprotein (C) and triglycerides (D) are lipid levels that are not directly related to the presence of a Baker's cyst.

So, the answer is [A]. Rheumatoid factor.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:05:13,445 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 3-year-old boy presents with episodic diarrhea with malodorous stools, stunted growth, occasional abdominal cramps, and an itchy rash. Supplementary feeding was started with non-starchy vegetable followed by starchy vegetables, meat, fish, eggs, and bread. Bread and cookies were the last product to be introduced at the age of 12 months. The patient’s mother tried to withdraw dairy products from the patient’s diet because she heard that lactose can cause such symptoms, but it did not help. The patient’s vital signs include: blood pressure 90/55 mm Hg, heart rate 101/min, respiratory rate 19/min, and temperature 36.3℃ (97.3℉). His weight is 11 kg (24.2 lb, -2 SD) and height is 90 cm (2 ft 11 in, -1 SD). On physical examination, the patient’s skin is pale with a papulovesicular rash on his abdomen and back. There are a few aphthous ulcers in the oral cavity. The abdomen is distended but no tenderness to palpation. No hepatosplenomegaly. An immunological assay is performed and shows positive anti-transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies. Which of the following changes would you most likely expect to see on intestinal biopsy in this patient?

[A] : Granulomas in the submucous tissue
[B] : Crypt abscesses
[C] : Villous atrophy and crypt hypertrophy
[D] : Villous hyperplasia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of episodic diarrhea with malodorous stools, stunted growth, occasional abdominal cramps, and an itchy rash, along with the presence of aphthous ulcers in the oral cavity, are suggestive of celiac disease. The fact that the patient's symptoms developed after the introduction of wheat-containing products (bread and cookies) and that dairy removal did not alleviate the symptoms further supports this diagnosis.

The immunological assay showing positive anti-transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies is highly specific for celiac disease. These antibodies are indicative of an autoimmune response to gluten, which is found in wheat, barley, and rye.

The characteristic histopathological findings in the small intestine of patients with celiac disease are villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia. Villous atrophy refers to the flattening of the villi, which are finger-like projections in the small intestine that increase the surface area for nutrient absorption. Crypt hypertrophy is the enlargement of the crypts of Lieberkühn, which are the glands found at the base of the villi.

Granulomas in the submucous tissue (choice A) are more characteristic of Crohn's disease, not celiac disease. Crypt abscesses (choice B) can be seen in inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis. Villous hyperplasia (choice D) is not a feature of celiac disease; rather, it is the opposite, with villous atrophy being the hallmark.

So, the answer is [C]. Villous atrophy and crypt hypertrophy.<|end|>

[B] : Generalized anxiety disorder

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation. Individuals with this disorder want to have relationships with others but are held back by their fear of being ridiculed or rejected.

Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by acute discomfort in close relationships, cognitive or perceptual distortions, and eccentricities of behavior, which does not seem to fit the daughter's presentation.

Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about a variety of topics, events, or activities. It is not specifically related to social interactions or the fear of rejection.

Dependent personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive psychological dependence on other people, but it does not typically include the fear of rejection or feelings of inadequacy that are central to the daughter's concerns.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

[C] : Adverse effect of anesthetic

<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with fever, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly. Acalculous cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and fever, and there is no evidence of gallbladder inflammation on the ultrasound. Gram-negative bacteremia could cause sepsis and liver injury, but the patient's presentation is more consistent with a post-anesthetic complication.

Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is an adverse effect of anesthetic agents, which can lead to malignant hyperthermia and subsequent liver injury.

So, the answer is [C]. Adverse effect of anesthetic.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:06:58,334 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 10-year-old African American girl with known sickle cell disease becomes acutely anemic in the setting of underlying infection. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a few episodes of acute pain crisis and a need for splenectomy 3 years ago. The vital signs upon arrival include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 106/74 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min and regular, and respiratory rate 17/min. On physical examination, her pulses are bounding and fingernails are pale, but breath sounds remain clear. Oxygen saturation was initially 91% on room air and electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia. A blood transfusion is initiated. Shortly after the transfusion has begun, the patient experiences fevers, chills, a burning sensation at the intravenous (IV) site, and sudden hypotension. What is the name of this reaction, and what is the best treatment?

[A] : Nonhemolytic febrile reaction; administer antihistamines
[B] : Minor allergic reaction; discontinue transfusion
[C] : Hemolytic transfusion reaction; administer antihistamines
[D] : Hemolytic transfusion reaction; discontinue transfusion
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing fevers, chills, a burning sensation at the IV site, and sudden hypotension shortly after a blood transfusion has begun. These symptoms are suggestive of a transfusion reaction.

A nonhemolytic febrile transfusion reaction (Option A) typically presents with fever and chills but does not usually cause hypotension or a burning sensation at the IV site.

A minor allergic reaction (Option B) could cause a burning sensation at the IV site and possibly fever, but it would not typically cause hypotension.

A hemolytic transfusion reaction (Option C) can present with fever, chills, and a feeling of warmth or burning at the IV site due to the body's reaction to the destruction of red blood cells. However, the administration of antihistamines is not the treatment of choice for a hemolytic transfusion reaction.

A hemolytic transfusion reaction (Option D) is a serious complication that can occur when the blood types of the donor and recipient are not compatible. It can cause fever, chills, hypotension, and a rapid heart rate. The best treatment for a hemolytic transfusion reaction is to immediately stop the transfusion and to manage the patient's symptoms, which may include supportive care and possibly medications to stabilize blood pressure.

Given the symptoms of fever, chills, a burning sensation at the IV site, and sudden hypotension, the most likely diagnosis is a hemolytic transfusion reaction. The best treatment is to discontinue the transfusion immediately.

So, the answer is [D]. Hemolytic transfusion reaction; discontinue transfusion.<|end|>

[D] : Copper

Gout is more common in men and can be precipitated by factors such as obesity, high alcohol intake, and certain medications. The acute presentation with severe pain, redness, and swelling is characteristic of a gout attack, often referred to as a "gout flare."

[A]. Stress fracture of proximal tibia - This is less likely because the patient's pain is not localized to the tibia itself, and stress fractures typically present with pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest.

[B]. Medial meniscus tear - This could be a possibility as the medial meniscus is located on the inside of the knee. However, meniscal tears often present with joint line tenderness and sometimes with a positive McMurray's test, which is not mentioned in the case.

[C]. Medical collateral ligament (MCL) sprain - The MCL is located on the inner side of the knee and could be injured with a valgus force, but the patient's valgus stress test was negative, making this diagnosis less likely.

[D]. Pes anserine bursitis - This condition involves inflammation of the bursa located between the tibia and the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles. The patient's symptoms and the localized tenderness over the anteromedial tibia are consistent with pes anserine bursitis. Additionally, the absence of joint effusion and the negative valgus stress test further support this diagnosis over the others.

So, the answer is [D]. Pes anserine bursitis.<|end|>

[A] : Tamoxifen
[B] : Terbutaline
[C] : Mifepristone
[D] : Copper intrauterine device
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is seeking a medical abortion for a 6-week pregnancy. The standard regimen for medical abortion involves the use of two medications: mifepristone and misoprostol. Mifepristone is an antiprogestin that works by blocking the action of progesterone, which is necessary for the pregnancy to continue. Misoprostol is a prostaglandin that causes the uterus to contract and expel the pregnancy.

Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that can be used to relax the uterus and delay preterm labor, but it is not used for abortion. The copper intrauterine device (IUD) is a form of long-term contraception and is not used for abortion.

Given the options provided, mifepristone is the correct choice for a medical abortion.

So, the answer is [C]. Mifepristone.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:09:30,653 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of periodic painful double vision for 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

[A] : Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
[B] : Compressive tumor of the pons
[C] : Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency
[D] : Infarction of the brainstem
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is presenting with symptoms of periodic painful double vision, which occurs only when looking sideways, and an adduction deficit in one eye with nystagmus in the other eye when looking in the opposite direction. This clinical picture is suggestive of a cranial nerve palsy affecting the sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve), which is responsible for lateral eye movement. The presence of nystagmus in the contralateral eye also indicates a possible involvement of the vestibular system or the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The MLF is a neural tract that coordinates eye movements and head movements. It connects the abducens nucleus of one side to the oculomotor nucleus of the opposite side. A lesion in the MLF can cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which is characterized by impaired adduction of the affected eye and nystagmus of the abducting eye. This condition is often associated with demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis (MS), especially in young adults.

The other options can be considered based on the clinical presentation:

[B]. Compressive tumor of the pons - This could cause cranial nerve palsies, but the patient's symptoms are more consistent with INO, and there is no mention of other neurological deficits that would suggest a compressive lesion.

[C]. Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency - This is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which typically presents with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. The patient's symptoms do not fully align with this diagnosis.

[D]. Infarction of the brainstem - While brainstem infarction can cause cranial nerve palsies, the patient's symptoms are more specific to INO, and there is no evidence of other brainstem signs such as altered consciousness or other cranial nerve deficits.

Given the patient's age, the nature of her symptoms, and the findings on examination, the most likely cause of her findings is demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.

So, the answer is [A]. Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.<|end|>

[C] : Femoral-to-popliteal bypass graft
[D] : Interventional endovascular treatment
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of calf pain when walking a distance of more than 200 meters, which subsides with rest, are suggestive of claudication, a common symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The treatment options listed are:

[A]. Cilostazol - This is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that can improve symptoms of claudication in patients with PA[D]. It works by inhibiting platelet aggregation and dilating arteries.

[D]. Interventional endovascular treatment - This includes procedures such as angioplasty or stenting to open up blocked arteries. This is usually considered for patients with critical limb ischemia or when there is a significant blockage that is causing severe symptoms.

Given that the patient's symptoms are chronic and there is no mention of critical limb ischemia or severe blockage, the first-line treatment to improve symptoms of claudication would be medical therapy with cilostazol, which can help increase walking distance and improve quality of life.

So, the answer is [A]. Cilostazol.<|end|>

A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?

[A] : Electroencephalography
[B] : Magnetic resonance angiography
[C] : Deep tendon reflex testing
[D] : Corneal reflex test
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient in the scenario has suffered a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury, which are both life-threatening conditions that can lead to brain death. Brain death is defined as the irreversible loss of all functions of the brain, including the brainstem.

The diagnosis of brain death involves a clinical assessment that includes the absence of cerebral and brainstem reflexes, as well as the inability to breathe independently, as evidenced by the patient's unresponsiveness and the fact that she is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The options provided are different tests that can be used to assess various aspects of neurological function:

[A]. Electroencephalography (EEG) measures electrical activity in the brain. While it can show a lack of brain activity, it is not typically used as a primary test for brain death because it does not assess brainstem reflexes or the ability to breathe independently.

[B]. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is an imaging technique used to visualize blood vessels in the brain. It is not used to diagnose brain death but could be used to assess for vascular injury or other structural abnormalities.

[C]. Deep tendon reflex testing assesses the reflex arc from the peripheral nerves to the spinal cord and brain. While it can provide information about the peripheral nervous system, it does not assess brainstem reflexes or brain function.

[D]. Corneal reflex test assesses the integrity of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and the facial nerve (CN VII). The corneal reflex involves blinking in response to stimulation of the cornea. This reflex is mediated by the brainstem, and its absence is one of the clinical signs used to assess for brainstem function and brain death.

Given that the patient is unresponsive and has dilated pupils that are not reactive to light, which indicates a lack of brainstem reflexes, the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death would be to perform a clinical examination to assess brainstem reflexes, including the corneal reflex test.

So, the answer is [D]. Corneal reflex test.<|end|>

[A]. 2025-12-12 04:13:16,698 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Please refer to the summary above to answer this question
A cardiologist at another institution is trying to replicate the table in the abstract with a very similar study that he is conducting. After collecting data on changes in plaque volume, LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores from baseline to 12-month follow-up, he is curious if the changes in the aforementioned measurements are statistically significant. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical method to compare the groups?"
"Impact of pulmharkimab on asthma control and cardiovascular disease progression in patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma
Introduction:
Active asthma has been found to be associated with a more than two-fold increase in the risk of myocardial infarction, even after adjusting for cardiovascular risk factors. It has been suggested that the inflammatory mediators and accelerated atherosclerosis characterizing systemic inflammation may increase the risk of both asthma and cardiovascular disease. This study evaluated the efficacy of the novel IL-1 inhibitor pulmharkimab in improving asthma and cardiovascular disease progression.
Methods:
In this double-blind, randomized controlled trial, patients (N=1200) with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction in the past 2 years, and a diagnosis of comorbid adult-onset asthma were recruited from cardiology clinics at a large academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA. Patients who were immunocompromised or had a history of recurrent infections were excluded.
Patients were subsequently randomly assigned a 12-month course of pulmharkimab 75 mg/day, pulmharkimab 150 mg/day, or a placebo, with each group containing 400 participants. All participants were included in analysis and analyzed in the groups to which they were randomized regardless of medication adherence. Variables measured included plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ) scores, which quantified the severity of asthma symptoms. Plaque volume was determined by ultrasound.
Analyses were performed from baseline to month 12.
Results:
At baseline, participants in the two groups did not differ by age, gender, race, plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores (p > 0.05 for all). A total of 215 participants (18%) were lost to follow-up. At 12-month follow-up, the groups contained the following numbers of participants:
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d: 388 participants
Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d: 202 participants
Placebo: 395 participants
Table 1: Association between pulmharkimab and both pulmonary and cardiovascular outcomes. Models were adjusted for sociodemographic variables and medical comorbidities. All outcome variables were approximately normally distributed.
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE) Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d, (Mean +/- 2 SE) Placebo, (Mean +/- 2 SE) P-value
Plaque volume (mm3), change from baseline 6.6 ± 2.8 1.2 ± 4.7 15.8 ± 2.9 < 0.01
LDL-C levels, change from baseline -9.4 ± 3.6 -11.2 ± 14.3 -8.4 ± 3.9 0.28
FEV1/FVC ratio, change from baseline 0.29 ± 2.21 0.34 ± 5.54 -0.22 ± 3.21 0.27
ACQ scores, change from baseline 0.31 ± 1.22 0.46 ± 3.25 0.12 ± 1.33 0.43
Conclusion:
Pulmharkimab may be effective in reducing plaque volume but does not lead to improved asthma control in patients with a history of myocardial infarction and comorbid asthma.
Source of funding: Southeast Institute for Advanced Lung and Cardiovascular Studies, American Center for Advancement of Cardiovascular Health"

[A] : Pearson correlation analysis
[B] : Chi-square test
[C] : Analysis of variance
[D] : Kaplan-Meier analysis
<|end|><|assistant|> The study described is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of two different doses of pulmharkimab and a placebo on patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma. The outcomes measured are continuous variables (plaque volume, LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores) and are compared at baseline and at 12-month follow-up.

Given that the outcomes are continuous and normally distributed, and the study involves comparing means across more than two groups (two doses of pulmharkimab and a placebo), the most appropriate statistical method to compare the groups would be the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). ANOVA is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups.

Pearson correlation analysis (A) is used to assess the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two continuous variables, not to compare group means. The Chi-square test (B) is used for categorical data to test the relationship between two variables, which is not the case here. Kaplan-Meier analysis (D) is used for survival analysis, which is not applicable to this study as it does not involve time-to-event data.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:13:38,737 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of heart palpitations for 3 weeks. The palpitations are accompanied by chest pain that is sharp and localized to the left 3rd intercostal space. The patient does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine on the weekends. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling. There is retraction of the left upper eyelid. A systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. The extremities are warm, and pulses are 2+ bilaterally. [A] : Propranolol
[B] : Digoxin
[C] : Amiodarone
[D] : Warfarin
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of heart palpitations, chest pain, an irregularly irregular pulse, and a systolic ejection murmur. These findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rapid ventricular response, given the irregularly irregular pulse and the presence of a murmur that could indicate underlying structural heart disease.

The patient's presentation also includes signs of hyperthyroidism, such as a fine tremor, digital swelling, and eyelid retraction. Hyperthyroidism is a known cause of AF and can exacerbate the condition.

Given the clinical scenario, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy would be to control the heart rate. Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, is effective for this purpose. It can help to control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the atrioventricular node.

Digoxin is not the first-line treatment for rate control in AF, especially in the setting of hyperthyroidism, as it can be less effective and has a narrow therapeutic window.

Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used for rhythm control in AF, but it is not the first choice for rate control and has a risk of serious side effects.

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is used for stroke prevention in patients with AF, but it does not address the immediate need for rate control.

So, the answer is [A]. Propranolol.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:13:51,711 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 78-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for sudden onset speech changes. He seems to be physically frustrated that no one understands him. Physical examination demonstrates weakness of the right arm. Damage to which location would best explain this patient’s symptoms?

[A] : Left frontal lobe
[B] : Left temporal lobe
[C] : Right frontal lobe
[D] : Right temporal lobe
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is presenting with sudden onset speech changes characterized by distorted speech with random and disconnected words, which is indicative of aphasia. Aphasia is a disorder caused by damage to the parts of the brain that control language. Since the patient is right-handed, it is more likely that his language centers are located in the left hemisphere of his brain, which is typically the dominant hemisphere for language in right-handed individuals.

The fact that the patient has weakness in the right arm suggests that the damage is not limited to the language centers but also affects the motor cortex, which is responsible for voluntary muscle movements. The motor cortex is located in the frontal lobe of the brain.

Given that the patient's speech is affected, and considering the typical lateralization of language functions in the brain, the most likely location of the damage would be in the left hemisphere, which controls language and motor functions of the opposite side of the body.

So, the answer is [A]. Left frontal lobe.<|end|>

One of the key features of HAV infection is that it can lead to an increase in the expression of MHC class I molecules on the surface of infected cells. Normally, MHC class I molecules present endogenously synthesized peptides (such as those from viruses that replicate within the cell) to CD8+ T cells. However, HAV can cause an upregulation of MHC class I molecules, which can lead to the presentation of exogenously synthesized antigens.

Finally, he has become extremely paranoid about government surveillance and has had hallucinations about secret agents in their house. His previous medical history is significant for a previous car crash in which the patient required internal fixation of a femur fracture and a corneal transplant for corneal degeneration. Otherwise he had no neurologic deficits prior to 6 weeks ago. Physical exam reveals myoclonus and ataxia. Which of the following is true of the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

[A] : Can be transmitted on medical equipment even after autoclaving instruments
[B] : Contains genetic material but is unable to survive independent from a host
[C] : Has a cell wall containing peptidoglycan
[D] : Leads to intracellular aggregations of hyperphosphorylated tau protein
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms include progressive memory loss, confusion, myoclonus (rapid jerky movements), ataxia (coordination and balance problems), paranoia, and hallucinations. These symptoms are suggestive of a prion disease, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). Prion diseases are a group of rare, fatal brain disorders that lead to rapid neurodegeneration.

Now let's evaluate the options:

[A]. Prions can indeed be transmitted through medical equipment, and they are notoriously difficult to inactivate even after autoclaving. This is because prions are highly resistant to conventional sterilization methods.

[B]. Prions do contain genetic material (DNA), but they are not considered living organisms and cannot replicate independently of a host. They are misfolded proteins that induce other normal proteins to misfold as well.

[C]. Prions do not have a cell wall containing peptidoglycan. Peptidoglycan is a component of bacterial cell walls, and prions are not bacteria.

[D]. Prion diseases are associated with intracellular aggregations of hyperphosphorylated tau protein. The misfolded prion proteins cause the tau proteins to also misfold, leading to the formation of neurofibrillary tangles, which are a hallmark of prion diseases and other neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer's disease.

Given the information and the options provided, the most accurate statement about the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms (a prion disease) is that it leads to intracellular aggregations of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient not being affected?

[A] : Variable expressivity
[B] : Maternal uniparental disomy
[C] : Gonadal mosaicism
[D] : Incomplete penetrance
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's older brother died at a young age from heart failure, and his nephew has severe muscle weakness. These symptoms suggest a genetic disorder that affects the heart and muscles. The fact that the patient's mother is not a carrier of the mutation responsible for the disease in his relatives is a critical piece of information.

[A]. Variable expressivity refers to the range of signs and symptoms that can occur in different people with the same genetic condition. However, this does not explain why the patient is not affected despite his family history.

[B]. Maternal uniparental disomy occurs when a person inherits two copies of a chromosome, or part of a chromosome, from one parent and no copies from the other parent. This could potentially explain why the patient is not affected if he inherited two copies of the mutated gene from his mother, but since the mother is not a carrier, this is not a plausible explanation.

[C]. Gonadal mosaicism is a condition where some of a person's germ cells (sperm or eggs) carry a genetic mutation, but the mutation is not present in the rest of the body's cells. This could explain why the patient is not affected if his mother has gonadal mosaicism for the mutation, and thus she does not carry it in her somatic cells, even though it is present in her germ cells.

[D]. Incomplete penetrance refers to the situation where some individuals who carry a disease-causing mutation do not exhibit the symptoms of the disease. This does not explain why the patient is not affected since the mutation is present in his family history.

Given the information provided, the most likely explanation is gonadal mosaicism. The mother may have the mutation in some of her germ cells but not in her somatic cells, which is why she does not show symptoms and is not a carrier in the traditional sense. The patient could have inherited the mutation from his mother through one of her germ cells, but since the mutation is not present in her somatic cells, he does not show symptoms of the disease.

So, the answer is [C]. Gonadal mosaicism.<|end|>
2025-12-12 04:19:18,337 - INFO - question 1144/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-12 04:19:50,709 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 58-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician with concerns about several recent health changes. The patient has recently gained weight and can't seem to exercise like she used to. She also notes that her thinking seems slow. Physical examination shows thickened, dry skin. Serum analysis confirms the physician's suspicions. Which of the following findings was most helpful in the diagnosis?

[A] : High T4 and T3
[B] : Low T4 and T3
[C] : High TSH
[D] : Hypercholesterolemia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of weight gain, decreased exercise tolerance, slow thinking, and thickened, dry skin are suggestive of hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones.

The thyroid hormones include thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In primary hypothyroidism, the problem lies in the thyroid gland itself, which is not producing sufficient hormones. This would typically result in low levels of T4 and T3 in the blood.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is produced by the pituitary gland and stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T4 and T3. In primary hypothyroidism, because the thyroid gland is underactive, the pituitary gland will typically produce more TSH in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones. Therefore, a high TSH level is indicative of primary hypothyroidism.

Hypercholesterolemia (high cholesterol levels) can be a secondary effect of hypothyroidism, as thyroid hormones are involved in lipid metabolism. However, it is not as specific or as helpful in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism as the levels of thyroid hormones and TSH.

Given the information provided, the most helpful finding in the diagnosis of this patient's condition would be a high TSH level, which indicates that the pituitary gland is responding to low thyroid hormone levels by trying to stimulate the thyroid gland.

So, the answer is [C]. High TSH.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:20:07,717 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 33-year-old woman at 17-weeks gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. A biopsy of the mass shows rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

[A] : Fibroadenoma
[B] : Normal pregnancy-related changes
[C] : Fat necrosis
[D] : Phyllodes tumor
<|end|><|assistant|> The description of the mass as rubbery, mobile, and nontender, along with the biopsy findings of overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue, is characteristic of a fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that are most common in young women and can occur during pregnancy or in the postpartum period. They are typically painless and can feel firm and smooth.

Normal pregnancy-related changes in the breast can include increased size, tenderness, and sometimes cysts, but these changes are usually not described as a discrete rubbery mass.

Fat necrosis of the breast can occur after trauma or surgery and can present as a firm, mobile mass. However, it is often associated with skin changes or nipple retraction and can sometimes be tender.

Phyllodes tumors are rare fibroepithelial lesions that can be benign or malignant. They tend to grow quickly and can be larger than fibroadenomas. They are less common than fibroadenomas and usually present with a rapidly enlarging mass.

Given the description of the mass and the biopsy findings, the most likely diagnosis is a fibroadenoma.

So, the answer is [A]. Fibroadenoma.<|end|>

Administering a blood transfusion against the patient's wishes would be a violation of his autonomy and could have legal and ethical repercussions.

Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following modifications to his insulin regimen would you recommend to this patient and his parents?

[A] : Increase the frequency of blood glucose checks.
[B] : Reduce the insulin dose.
[C] : Continue same regimen.
[D] : Hold insulin until the patient gets better.
<|end|><|assistant|> In patients with type 1 diabetes, insulin is a critical component of their management and cannot be skipped or reduced without risking serious complications, including diabetic ketoacidosis. When a patient with type 1 diabetes has an illness, especially with a fever, their insulin requirements may increase due to the stress of the illness and the counter-regulatory hormones that are released in response to infection. Therefore, it is generally recommended to:

[B]. Do not reduce the insulin dose, as this could lead to dangerously high blood glucose levels.

[C]. Continue the same regimen is not advisable because the illness can affect blood glucose levels.

[D]. Do not hold insulin, as this could also lead to hyperglycemia and its associated risks.

Given these considerations, the best course of action is to increase the frequency of blood glucose checks to ensure that the patient's blood glucose levels are being managed appropriately during the illness.

2025-12-12 04:20:54,937 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A researcher evaluates healthy breast tissue from 100 women, 50 women that were pregnant at the time of the study and 50 age-matched non-pregnant women. The breast tissue in pregnant women contained an increased number of acinar glands with epithelial proliferation compared to the non-pregnant women. Which process caused this change?

[A] : Hyperplasia
[B] : Hypertrophy
[C] : Atrophy
[D] : Metaplasia
<|end|><|assistant|> The breast tissue in pregnant women showed an increased number of acinar glands with epithelial proliferation. This indicates that there is an increase in the number of cells. 

Hyperplasia is the process where there is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, which can lead to an increase in the size of the organ or tissue. This is different from hypertrophy, where the cells increase in size but not in number. Atrophy is the opposite of hyperplasia and hypertrophy, where there is a decrease in the size of the cells or the entire organ or tissue. Metaplasia is a change in the type of cells that an organ or tissue contains, which is not the case here.

Since the breast tissue in pregnant women has an increased number of acinar glands due to epithelial proliferation, the process that caused this change is hyperplasia.

So, the answer is [A]. Hyperplasia.<|end|>

[B] : Lipodystrophy
[C] : Myelosuppression
[D] : Peripheral neuropathy

[B] : Transient (functional) proteinuria
[C] : Orthostatic proteinuria
[D] : Isolated proteinuria

[A] : T-score of 1.2
[B] : T-score of -0.8
[C] : Z-score of -2.0
[D] : T-score of -1.6
<|end|><|assistant|> Osteopenia is a condition where bone mineral density is lower than normal peak BMD but not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis. The World Health Organization (WHO) has established criteria for diagnosing osteopenia and osteoporosis using DEXA scan results.

The T-score is a comparison of the patient's bone mineral density to that of a healthy 30-year-old adult. According to the WHO:

- A T-score of -1.0 or above is considered normal.
- A T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 indicates osteopenia.
- A T-score of -2.5 or below is diagnostic for osteoporosis.

Given the options provided:

[A]. A T-score of 1.2 would indicate normal bone density, which is not consistent with osteopenia.
[B]. A T-score of -0.8 is within the normal range and does not indicate osteopenia.
[C]. A Z-score is a comparison of the patient's bone mineral density to what is expected in someone of the same age and sex, but it is not the standard measure for diagnosing osteopenia or osteoporosis.
[D]. A T-score of -1.6 falls within the range of -1.0 to -2.5, which is consistent with a diagnosis of osteopenia.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:24:02,649 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, weakness, and difficulty feeding. He was delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman. He is not able to sit upright on his own. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 50/min. His tongue protrudes beyond the teeth. Neck veins are distended. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows profound weakness in proximal and distal muscles of the upper and lower extremities. He has 2+ reflexes bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly. Serum glucose is 105 mg/dL. Which of the following is the enzyme most likely to be defective in this patient?

[A] : Muscle glycogen phosphorylase
[B] : Very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase
[C] : Lysosomal acid maltase
[D] : Glycogen debranching enzyme
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the 7-month-old boy includes symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, difficulty feeding, inability to sit upright, an enlarged tongue (macroglossia), distended neck veins, crackles at the lung bases, an S3 gallop on cardiac examination, hepatomegaly, and profound weakness in both proximal and distal muscles. These findings suggest a diagnosis of a glycogen storage disease (GSD), which is a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues.

The presence of cardiomegaly and an S3 gallop suggests cardiac involvement, which is characteristic of Pompe disease (GSD type II). Pompe disease is caused by a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase (also known as lysosomal acid maltase), which is responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within the lysosomes. The accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes leads to the symptoms observed in Pompe disease, including muscle weakness and cardiomegaly.

The other options listed are enzymes associated with different types of GSDs:

[A]. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency is associated with McArdle disease (GSD type V), which typically presents with exercise intolerance and muscle cramps but not with cardiomegaly or the other systemic symptoms seen in this patient.

[B]. Very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is associated with peroxisomal disorders, not GSDs, and would not typically present with the symptoms described.

[D]. Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency is associated with Andersen disease (GSD type III), which can present with liver disease and progressive liver failure, but the cardiac involvement is not as prominent as in Pompe disease.

Given the clinical presentation and the enzyme deficiencies associated with different types of GSDs, the most likely enzyme to be defective in this patient is lysosomal acid maltase.

So, the answer is [C]. Lysosomal acid maltase.<|end|>

Serum:

HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL

Leukocyte count: 5,500/mm^3

Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient's underlying condition?

[A] : IM haloperidol
[B] : Clozapine
[C] : Urine toxicology
[D] : ANA and anti-dsDNA levels
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with a history of depression and anxiety, a known history of medication non-compliance, and an episode of aggressive behavior. The presence of multiple oral ulcers and a friction rub on cardiac exam could suggest an underlying autoimmune condition, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The elevated reticulocyte count could indicate a hemolytic process, which is also consistent with SLE. The patient's serum creatinine is elevated, which could indicate kidney involvement, another common feature of SLE.

Given the clinical presentation and the lab findings, the next best step in management would be to confirm the diagnosis of SLE. This would involve checking for antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) levels, which are specific markers for SLE.

While urine toxicology (option C) could be considered given the patient's history of medication non-compliance and the acute change in behavior, the clinical findings are more suggestive of an underlying autoimmune process rather than intoxication or withdrawal.

IM haloperidol (option A) and clozapine (option B) are antipsychotic medications that could be used to manage acute agitation or psychosis. However, these medications would not address the underlying condition and could potentially worsen the patient's condition if an autoimmune disorder is the cause of her symptoms.

Therefore, the next best step in management for this patient's underlying condition is to check for ANA and anti-dsDNA levels to confirm the diagnosis of SLE.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:26:37,906 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 51-year-old Asian woman presents to her primary care provider with abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen. Further workup suggests ovarian cancer, which is confirmed later in the week to be stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this malignancy to have metastasized to the brain?

[A] : Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
[B] : Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
[C] : Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
[D] : Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
<|end|><|assistant|> The lymphatic drainage of the ovaries is to the para-aortic lymph nodes, which are located around the aorta at the level of the lumbar vertebrae. The lymph from the ovaries would first drain into the sentinel lymph node, which is the first node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.

After passing through the sentinel node, the lymph would then travel to the right or left lumbar trunk, depending on which side of the body the tumor is located. Since the patient has a tumor in the right ovary, the lymph would drain into the right lumbar trunk.

The right lumbar trunk then drains into the cisterna chyli, which is a dilated sac at the lower end of the thoracic duct into which the lymphatics of the intestinal trunk, right lumbar trunk, and the right thoracic duct flow.

The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic vessel that drains lymph from the lower half of the body and the left side of the upper body. It ascends through the chest and eventually empties into the venous system.

The thoracic duct typically empties into the left subclavian vein near the junction with the superior vena cava. From there, the lymph enters the systemic circulation and is filtered by the liver and kidneys before returning to the heart.

Given this information, the most likely route for the ovarian cancer to have metastasized to the brain would be through the lymphatic system, following the path from the sentinel node to the right lumbar trunk, then to the cisterna chyli, through the thoracic duct, and finally draining into the left subclavian vein before entering the systemic circulation and potentially reaching the brain.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

[A] : Simple ductal epithelium
[B] : Granulation tissue
[C] : Pyogenic membrane
[D] : Columnar mucinous epithelium

The CT scan, although not shown here, likely indicates a finding consistent with chronic pancreatitis, given the patient's history of alcohol use and his symptoms. Chronic pancreatitis can lead to malabsorption due to the insufficient production of pancreatic enzymes necessary for the digestion of fats, leading to steatorrhea (fatty stools that are bulky and foul-smelling).

The structure indicated by the arrows in the CT scan is most likely a pseudocyst, which is a common complication of chronic pancreatitis. Pseudocysts are fluid collections that arise due to pancreatic ductal injury and are not lined by epithelial cells. Instead, they are surrounded by a wall of fibrous tissue or granulation tissue.

Given the options provided:

[A]. Simple ductal epithelium - This would be found lining the pancreatic ducts, not a pseudocyst.
[B]. Granulation tissue - This is a type of tissue that forms during the healing process and can be found in pseudocysts.
[C]. Pyogenic membrane - This is associated with acute inflammation and infection, not chronic pancreatitis.
[D]. Columnar mucinous epithelium - This type of epithelium lines the intestines and some parts of the pancreas, but not pseudocysts.

The most likely lining for a pseudocyst resulting from chronic pancreatitis is granulation tissue.

So, the answer is [B]. Granulation tissue.<|end|>

[A] : Endocardial cushion
[B] : Infundibular septum
[C] : 3rd pharyngeal arch
[D] : Rathke’s pouch
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the child, including fatigue, difficulty catching breath, and a localized harsh pansystolic murmur over the left sternal border at the level of the 2nd–3rd intercostal space, is suggestive of a congenital heart defect. The murmur becoming louder when the patient squats is a characteristic finding in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is often due to a defect in the interventricular septum.

The interventricular septum is the structure that separates the left and right ventricles of the heart. A defect in this area can lead to a condition known as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, where the septum is abnormally thickened, obstructing blood flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle and causing the symptoms described.

The interventricular septum is derived from the endocardial cushions during embryonic development. The endocardial cushions are critical structures that contribute to the formation of the heart's septa and valves.

The infundibular septum is involved in the development of the outflow tract of the heart but is not the primary structure responsible for the septal defects seen in HCM.

The 3rd pharyngeal arch is involved in the development of structures in the neck and pharynx, not the heart.

Rathke’s pouch is an embryonic precursor to the anterior pituitary gland and is not related to the heart.

Given this information, the defective structure causing the patient's symptoms is most likely due to a problem with the endocardial cushions.

So, the answer is [A]. Endocardial cushion.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:29:50,008 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 26-year-old woman developed rapidly progressive septic shock associated with nuchal rigidity, petechiae, and purpura. Which one of the cytokines below takes part in the pathogenesis of septic shock?

[A] : Tumor necrosis factor-α
[B] : Interleukin-5
[C] : Interleukin-12
[D] : Interleukin-4
<|end|><|assistant|> Septic shock is a severe and systemic response to infection that can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and death. It is characterized by a dysregulated immune response to an infection, which includes the release of various cytokines and other inflammatory mediators.

Among the cytokines listed, Tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) is a key pro-inflammatory cytokine that plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of septic shock. TNF-α is produced by activated macrophages and other cells in response to infection and is involved in the systemic inflammation that characterizes septic shock. It can lead to increased vascular permeability, which contributes to edema, hypotension, and organ dysfunction.

Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is primarily involved in the growth and differentiation of eosinophils and is not typically associated with septic shock.

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is involved in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and the production of interferon-gamma, which is important for the immune response against intracellular pathogens, but it is not the primary cytokine implicated in the pathogenesis of septic shock.

Interleukin-4 (IL-4) is involved in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and is important for the immune response against extracellular pathogens, but like IL-12, it is not the primary cytokine implicated in the pathogenesis of septic shock.

So, the answer is [A]. Tumor necrosis factor-α.<|end|>

[C] : Eosinophilic esophagitis

[D]. Esophageal reflux disease (GERD) typically presents with heartburn and may lead to complications such as esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus. However, the patient has had heartburn for 2 years with no response to high-dose omeprazole, which makes GERD less likely.

Given the patient's history of atopic diseases (asthma and eczema), the difficulty swallowing solids, and the lack of response to GERD treatment, eosinophilic esophagitis is the most likely diagnosis.

[A]. Exertional heat stroke is a possibility, especially given the patient's occupation as a construction worker, which involves physical labor that could lead to heat exposure. However, the patient's recent history of anesthesia and the use of phenytoin for epilepsy make this less likely.

[B]. Malignant hyperthermia is a rare life-threatening condition usually triggered by exposure to certain anesthetic agents. The patient's recent anesthesia could be a clue, but malignant hyperthermia typically presents with a rapid onset of symptoms during or shortly after anesthesia, not months later.

[C]. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a serious condition associated with the use of antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol. It is characterized by hyperthermia, altered mental status, muscle rigidity, and autonomic dysfunction. The patient's use of haloperidol and the presence of hyperthermia and altered mental status make NMS a strong possibility.

[D]. Thyroid storm is a severe form of hyperthyroidism that can cause fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status. However, the patient's hyperthyroidism is being treated, and there is no mention of recent changes in his thyroid medication or status that would suggest a thyroid storm.

Given the patient's history of schizophrenia and the use of haloperidol, along with the presentation of hyperthermia, altered mental status, and tachycardia, NMS is the most likely diagnosis.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

The neurological and psychiatric symptoms, along with the macrocytic anemia, are suggestive of a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to impaired methylation of myelin phospholipids, which is necessary for the maintenance of myelin sheaths around nerves. Chronic acetaldehyde influence (B) is associated with alcohol abuse, but the patient drinks alcohol only occasionally, and his liver enzymes are normal. Influence of pseudo-neurotransmitters (D) is not supported by the clinical picture or the laboratory findings.

Therefore, the most likely explanation for the patient's neurological and psychiatric symptoms is impaired methylation of myelin phospholipids due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which is consistent with the macrocytic anemia and the neurological findings.

So, the answer is [C]. Impaired methylation of myelin phospholipids.<|end|>

[C] : Ribavirin
[D] : Lamivudine
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has tested positive for Hepatitis C surface antibody (HCV Ab) and Hepatitis C RNA, indicating a current Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. The high viral load (100,000,000 IU/ml) suggests active infection.

The treatment for chronic Hepatitis C has evolved significantly over the years, with the introduction of direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) that have high cure rates and fewer side effects compared to older treatments. Sofosbuvir and simeprevir are examples of DAAs that are commonly used in combination for the treatment of HCV.

Interferon-gamma is not used for the treatment of HCV; it is an immunomodulator with no role in antiviral therapy for HCV.

Ribavirin is an antiviral medication that was used in combination with interferon-alpha in the past for the treatment of HCV, but it is no longer the first-line treatment due to the availability of more effective and better-tolerated DAAs.

Lamivudine is an antiviral medication used to treat Hepatitis B, not Hepatitis [C].

Given the current guidelines and the patient's positive HCV RNA test, the appropriate treatment would be a combination of DAAs, such as sofosbuvir and simeprevir.

[D]. Increased serum amyloid A production - This is associated with secondary amyloidosis, which typically occurs in the context of chronic inflammatory conditions. Given the patient's history of rheumatoid arthritis and the clinical presentation, renal deposition of AL amyloid is the most likely cause of his findings.

2025-12-12 04:35:07,027 - INFO - question 1180/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-12 04:35:42,151 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. Current medications include glyburide and amlodipine. The physician prescribes a medication that decreases the production of mevalonate. Which of the following changes to the serum is most likely to develop as an adverse effect of the prescribed drug?

[A] : Increased creatine kinase concentration
[B] : Decreased glucose concentration
[C] : Increased triglyceride concentration
[D] : Increased bradykinin concentration
<|end|><|assistant|> The medication that decreases the production of mevalonate is likely a statin, which is commonly prescribed to lower cholesterol levels in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension and diabetes. Statins work by inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which is a key enzyme in the mevalonate pathway responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol and other important biomolecules like coenzyme Q10.

One of the known side effects of statins is an increase in serum creatine kinase (CK) concentration. This is because statins can cause muscle damage, which leads to the release of CK into the bloodstream. This condition is known as statin-induced myopathy, and in severe cases, it can lead to rhabdomyolysis, a serious syndrome resulting from the breakdown of muscle tissue.

The other options listed are not typically associated with statin use:

[B]. Decreased glucose concentration is not a common side effect of statins. In fact, some studies suggest that statins may slightly increase the risk of developing diabetes, not decrease glucose levels.

[C]. Increased triglyceride concentration is not a typical side effect of statins. Statins are more likely to decrease triglyceride levels.

[D]. Increased bradykinin concentration is not associated with statin use. Bradykinin levels are more commonly affected by drugs that inhibit the enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), such as ACE inhibitors.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

Sodium 141 mEq/L

Glucose 109 mg/dL
Cortisol (1600 h) 4 μg/dL
Prolactin 14 ng/mL
17-hydroxyprogesterone 390 ng/dL (N=20–300 ng/dL)
Testosterone 91 ng/dL (N=8–60 ng/dL)
A urine pregnancy test is negative. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following?"

[A] : Hyperproliferation of theca interna cells
[B] : Exogenous anabolic steroid use
[C] : Ovarian fibrosis and multiple cystic follicles
[D] : Hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with signs of virilization, such as excess hair growth (hirsutism) on her face, irregular menses, and acne. These symptoms suggest an excess of androgens. The serum studies show elevated levels of testosterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

The elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone is a key finding here. This hormone is a precursor to cortisol, and its elevation suggests that there is an issue with the enzyme 21-hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol in the cortisol synthesis pathway. When 21-hydroxylase is deficient or not functioning properly, 17-hydroxyprogesterone accumulates, and there is a shunting of precursors towards androgen synthesis, leading to elevated levels of androgens.

This clinical picture is consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is a group of inherited disorders of the adrenal gland. The most common form of CAH is due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which leads to hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex as the gland attempts to compensate for the enzyme deficiency.

The other options can be considered but are less likely given the clinical and laboratory findings:

[A]. Hyperproliferation of theca interna cells is associated with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which typically presents with elevated androgens but would not explain the elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

[B]. Exogenous anabolic steroid use could cause elevated testosterone levels, but it would not explain the elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

[C]. Ovarian fibrosis and multiple cystic follicles are also associated with PCOS, which, again, would not account for the elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

Given the information provided, the most likely association is with hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex due to CAH.

So, the answer is [D].<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:37:00,883 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 64-year-old man with coronary artery disease and hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure ranged from 160/100 mm Hg to 150/94 mm Hg on his previous 3 visits over the past 4 months. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and metoprolol. Three weeks ago, he was also started on amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 158/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Renal duplex ultrasonography shows 90% occlusion of the right renal artery. Decreased renal blood flow is most likely to cause which of the following?

[A] : Hyperplasia of juxtaglomerular cells
[B] : Dilation of efferent arteriole
[C] : Decreased prostaglandin synthesis by macula densa
[D] : Decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate at proximal tubule
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a significant occlusion of the right renal artery, which is likely causing reduced blood flow to the affected kidney. This condition is known as renal artery stenosis. When the kidney perceives a decrease in blood flow, it responds by activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

Here's how the RAAS works in this context:

1. The juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney, which are located near the glomerulus, sense the decreased blood flow.
2. In response, the juxtaglomerular cells release renin into the bloodstream.
3. Renin converts angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) into angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) primarily in the lungs.
4. Angiotensin II has multiple effects, including vasoconstriction of blood vessels and stimulating the secretion of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex.
5. Aldosterone promotes sodium and water retention, which increases blood volume and blood pressure.
6. Angiotensin II also causes constriction of the efferent arterioles of the glomerulus, which helps to maintain glomerular filtration pressure despite the reduced renal blood flow.

Given these points, let's evaluate the options:

[A]. Hyperplasia of juxtaglomerular cells - This is a likely response to chronic activation of the RAAS due to decreased renal blood flow.

[B]. Dilation of efferent arteriole - This is incorrect because angiotensin II, which is increased due to RAAS activation, actually causes constriction of the efferent arteriole.

[C]. Decreased prostaglandin synthesis by macula densa - This is not directly related to the effects of decreased renal blood flow on the RAAS.

[D]. Decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate at proximal tubule - This is not a direct consequence of decreased renal blood flow or activation of the RAAS.

The most likely response to decreased renal blood flow due to renal artery stenosis is the activation of the RAAS, which includes the release of renin by the juxtaglomerular cells and subsequent effects on the kidney, including the constriction of the efferent arteriole to maintain glomerular filtration pressure.

So, the answer is [A]. Hyperplasia of juxtaglomerular cells.<|end|>

2025-12-12 04:37:33,449 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband after he found her with nausea, headache, and agitation 1 hour ago. When he left their lakeside cabin 6 hours before to go ice fishing and get more firewood, she did not have any symptoms. She has chronic migraines, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include lisinopril and metformin, but she ran out of her anti-hypertensive medications over the weekend. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 154/92 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls only one of three objects after 5 minutes. Her gait is unsteady. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's current condition?

[A] : Intravenous nitroprusside
[B] : Hyperbaric oxygen therapy
[C] : 100% oxygen therapy
[D] : Heliox therapy
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's presentation of sudden onset of nausea, headache, agitation, confusion, and an unsteady gait after being in a lakeside cabin without symptoms prior to her husband leaving suggests a possible case of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. CO poisoning is common in enclosed spaces with poor ventilation, especially where combustion devices like fireplaces or gas heaters are used. The symptoms of CO poisoning can be nonspecific and mimic other conditions such as stroke or heart attack.

The fact that she ran out of her anti-hypertensive medications over the weekend could have led to uncontrolled hypertension, which is a risk factor for stroke. However, the acute onset of symptoms and the context of being in a lakeside cabin suggest CO poisoning as a more likely diagnosis.

The treatment for CO poisoning is to immediately remove the patient from the source of exposure and administer 100% oxygen therapy. This helps to displace CO from the hemoglobin, allowing for the restoration of oxygen transport in the blood.

Intravenous nitroprusside (choice A) is a vasodilator used to treat hypertensive emergencies, but it is not the treatment for CO poisoning. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (choice B) is an option for severe CO poisoning, but it is not the first-line treatment and is not available in all settings. Heliox therapy (choice D) is a mixture of helium and oxygen used to reduce airway resistance in obstructive lung diseases, which is not indicated in this case.

So, the answer is [C]. 100% oxygen therapy.<|end|>

Imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum. Which of this patient's coronary arteries is most likely occluded?

[A] : Left circumflex
[B] : Diagonal perforators
[C] : Septal perforators
[D] : Right main
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is presenting with symptoms of a myocardial infarction (MI), specifically severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. The imaging has revealed a transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum. This location is typically supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is usually a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) in most individuals (approximately 70-80% of the population).

The left circumflex artery (LCX) typically supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle, but it is not usually responsible for the posterior third of the interventricular septum.

Diagonal perforators are not a recognized term in coronary anatomy; the term "perforator" refers to the relationship between the coronary arteries and the cardiac muscle, not a specific artery.

Septal perforators are also not a recognized term in coronary anatomy.

The right main coronary artery (RCA) is the artery that typically gives rise to the PDA in the majority of the population.

Given the location of the infarction and the typical coronary anatomy, the most likely occluded artery in this patient is the right main coronary artery, which would lead to occlusion of the PDA and result in a transmural infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum.

So, the answer is [D]. Right main.<|end|>
